characters: THE TABLE AND THE REST OF THE FOOD ON THE TA
CAMERA GETTING NEAR THE HOUSE AND BARN
SIGN ON DOOR OUT TO LUNCH TWO SHOT
A CLUSTER OF BUILDINGS AT WATERFRONT
MAN AND WOMAN NEXT TO HIM
MELANIE ICY DETERMINATION ON HER FACE.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT STREET
dialogues.text: It is mid-afternoon, and there is a tempo and pace to the people walking, the doorman HOOTING for taxicabs, the  policemen directing traffic.

dialogues.speaker: PEDESTRIANS
dialogues.text: waiting at street corner for light to change.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: at the end of line of pedestrians. He is looking up at th sky.

dialogues.speaker: MAN AND WOMAN NEXT TO HIM
dialogues.text: as she follows his gaze upward.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: with hundreds of gulls in it, wheeling.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET CORNER
dialogues.text: as the light changes and people begin to cross. In the cr walking the other way, a man turns to look up at the whee gulls in the sky overhead. The CAMERA LOCATES:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE DANIELS
dialogues.text: in the crowd of pedestrians, approaching Davidson's Pet S She is a young woman in her mid-twenties, sleekly groomed exquisitely dressed, though hatless. She walks with the q sureness of the city dweller, a purposefulness in her str a mischievous grin on her face. She continues toward the  front door of a pet shop and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie opens the door and comes through, still looking b toward the street and skywards. The proprietor, a MRS.   MacGRUDER, comes toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. MacGruder, have you ever  seen so many gulls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacGruder takes a look out at the sky. A puppy is  BARKING, o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be a storm at sea. That  can drive them inland, you know. They are climbing the short flight of steps into the bird department now. The BARKING of the dog SEGUES into the cl of innumerable birds, TWEETING, TWITTERING, CAWING as Mel and Mrs. MacGruder go to the counter at the far end.  The is a circular cage in the center of the room, and the wal are lined with wire-mesh cages and smaller wooden cages s that the effect is one of being surrounded by birds, cont birds to be sure. The birds are quite beautiful, mostly e birds, small splashes of color behind the wire-mesh cages larger bursts of brilliant hue on the parrots and parakee in the bigger cages. As they walk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd be a little late,  Miss Daniels. (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, he hasn't arrived yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said three o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Oh, I know. (she is more distressed  now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been calling all morning. Oh,  you have no idea. Miss Daniels,  they're so difficult to get, really  they are. We get them from India,  you know, when they're just little  chicks, and then we have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this one won't be a chick,  will he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. Oh, no. Certainly  not. This will be a full grown myna  bird. Full grown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he'll talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes, he'll talk. Well, no, no.  You'll have to teach him to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, I suppose I should call them  again. They said three o'clock. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's the traffic. I'll call.   Would you mind waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (judiciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe you'd better deliver  him. Let me give you my address. (she begins taking  off her gloves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (producing pencil and  pad)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, well, all right. As Melanie starts writing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they're on the way, though.   Could I just call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a resigned sigh)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right, but... She scurries out behind the counter and out of sight.  Me finishes writing her address and stands impatiently by th counter. She taps her teeth with the pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Betty MacGruder at  Davidson's. (pause; accusingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's past three, you know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how long do you think...? All  right, would you check it please?   Yes, I'll wait. Melanie sighs. Leaving her gloves and purse on the counte she begins wandering around the shop, still tapping her l with the pencil. There is no menace in the birds surround her. They are active and beautiful as they dart behind th bars and mesh of their cages. Off screen, the puppy begin BARKING again as the front door opens. Melanie looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH BRENNER
dialogues.text: as he closes the entrance door behind him and starts up t steps to the bird department. He is a handsome man, about twenty-nine or thirty, well-dressed, and carrying a felt  hat.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: seeing him, and then turning away to bend before the cage strawberry finches. She pokes the pencil through the mesh The birds are startled into scarlet flight.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as they pass each other in the aisle. He gives a polite l nod, and she gives a polite little smile. But as he passe her, and unknown to her, he turns for a second look -- an then vanishes behind the circular cage as he turns he cor

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking at her watch as she wanders around the other side the cage and then comes face to face with Mitch again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deliberately, and  with a touch of  hauteur)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I wonder if you could help  me.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: a trifle annoyed by his manner at first. She is about to  inform him, if you please, that she is not a shopgirl. Bu then something rebellious flashes in her eyes and an idea comes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solicitously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, what was it you were looking  for, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovebirds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovebirds, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I understand there are different  varieties, it that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yes, sir, there are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are for my sister... her  birthday you see. As she'll be eleven  and... well, frankly, I wouldn't  want a pair of birds that were too  demonstrative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand completely, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the same time, I wouldn't want  birds that were aloof, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leading him around  shop)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a pair that are just  friendly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so, sir. (she looks around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now then, let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the finches)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't these lovebirds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, those are... redbirds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sign says strawberry finches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (airily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we call them that too. (she moves away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, here we are, Lovebirds... (and stops before a  cage of canaries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are canaries, Miss. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't this make you feel awful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't what make me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these innocent little creatures  caged up like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we can't just let them fly  around the shop, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose not. Is there an  ornithological reason for keeping  them in separate cages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, certainly. It's to protect the  species.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I imagine that's very important.   Especially during the moulting season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's a particularly dangerous  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they moulting now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... they get a sort of hangdog  expression. CLOSE SHOT - A CAGED BIRD - MITCH'S P.O.V. The bird is wearing a distinctly hangdog expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I see. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About those lovebirds, Miss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you wouldn't like to  see a canary instead? We have some  very nice canaries this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, may I see one, please?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she realizes she is expected to take one of the canari out of the cage. She smiles feebly, glances toward the co where she expects Mrs. MacGruder to reappear momentarily, and then takes a deep breath. She opens the door to the c cage, and cautiously puts her hand into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feebly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, birdie. Here, birdie, birdie. One of the canaries suddenly flutters out of the cage and into the room. Melanie leaps back, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  Ohhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: THE BIRD DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: as the canary flies frantically about the room, Melanie a Mitch in pursuit. Mrs. MacGruder appears at the counter,  finally confronted with the chaos she's been expecting al day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Oh! Oh my, one of the  birds is loose! She joins in the chase around the room. The bird flutters to the ceiling, and then lands on the counter and watches them suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh! Shhhh! He tiptoes up to the bird, hat in hand. Quickly, he cover the bird with his hat, then reaches under to grab it.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: the canary in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There we are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good! Oh, wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIRD DEPARTMENT
dialogues.text: as Mitch carries the canary back to the cage. He opens th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the canary  in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back into your gilded cage, Melanie  Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (savoring this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was merely drawing a parallel,  Miss Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how... how do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (secretly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little birdie told me. (he smiles politely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Miss Daniels. (he bows to Mrs.   MacGruder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam. (he starts out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute! She goes after him. Mitch turns, stops, smiles, enjoying bafflement immensely. Melanie studies him. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, but I know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never met in court or anyplace  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true. I'll rephrase it. I saw  you in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember one of your practical  jokes that resulted in the smashing  of a plate glass window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't break that window!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but your little prank did. The  judge should have put you behind  bars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you? A policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply believe in the law, Miss  Daniels, and I'm not too keen on  practical jokers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call your lovebird story  if not a practical...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh, but I really do want those  birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew I didn't work here. You  deliberately...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I recognized you when I came  in. I thought you might like to know  what it felt like to be on the other  end of a gag. What do you think of  that, Miss Daniels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're a louse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. (he tips his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day. (to Mrs. MacGruder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam. (and he goes down the  steps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm glad you didn't get your  lovebirds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breezily, as he goes  out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find something else. (he gives a slight  bow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in court some day. The door closes. The puppy begins BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That... that... who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: seething as she stares after him. Suddenly, she gets an i

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: going down the steps and to the front door of the shop. S looks through the glass. LONG SHOT - MITCH - MELANIE'S P.O.V. getting into his car at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking after the car at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: THE LICENSE PLATE CLOSE SHOT
dialogues.text: seeing the plate, giving a brief, determined, angry nod. begins to repeat the numbers to herself as she turns.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she comes up the steps again and walks toward the coun MED. SHOT - MELANIE - MRS. MACGRUDER'S P.O.V. as she comes up to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a pencil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Oh, yes, certainly. As Melanie begins writing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said the myna bird would be  here later this afternoon. If you'd  care to come back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you'd better send him. May I use  your phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered by  everything)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, certainly. (she puts phone on  counter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she dials)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any lovebirds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not in the shop. But I can order  them for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... well, how soon would you  want them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the Daily News? Melanie  Daniels. Would you get me the city  desk, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might be able to have them by  tomorrow morning. Would that be all  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an edged anger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be just fine. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie, this is Melanie. I  want you to do a favor for me. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is a small one. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressure you? Why, Charlie darling,  would I try to pressure you?  Will  you call the Department of Motor  Vehicles for me and find out who  owns this license plate? DKQ dash  one seven six. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, a California plate. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll stop up there in a little  while. Is daddy in his office? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No, no, I don't want to break in  on a meeting. Just tell him I'll see  him later. Thank you, Charlie. (she hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. What time tomorrow morning?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE'S SPORTS CAR
dialogues.text: pulling up in front of Mitch's building, the top down. Sh glances up at the address, gets out of the car, comes aro to the other side, and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOVEBIRDS
dialogues.text: in a cage as Melanie reaches for them.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning from the car and going into the building. She pau in the lobby, studies the names alongside the bell button

dialogues.speaker: HER GLOVED HAND
dialogues.text: running down the list of names slowly. It stops.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARD
dialogues.text: her finger beside it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER, M. 3B
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - HER GLOVED HAND the forefinger extended as s runs it down over every bell button in one column, and th does the same for the next column.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she turns from the bells to the inner door of the lobb grabbing the knob. A BUZZ SOUNDS. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: coming through the door and into the lobby. She walks swi toward the elevator where a well-dressed man is standing, waiting. Behind her, the inner door is BUZZING wildly wit answering BUZZES. Melanie and the man stand waiting for t elevator, silently. Behind her, the BUZZING STOPS. The  elevator doors open. The man smiles pleasantly and allows her to enter first. She does so with a small nod.  The  elevator doors close.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND THE MAN
dialogues.text: The birds are CHIRPING wildly in their cage. The man and  Melanie stand silently side by side. The man's eyes wande down to the bird-cage. Melanie's eyes move toward him.  S consciously, she stands with the cage of CHATTERING birds The man is dead-panned, unsmiling. The elevator stops. Th doors begin to open.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: stepping out of the elevator as the doors open. The man i right behind her. She begins looking for apartment 3B. Th man is walking down the corridor beside her. She stops in front of the apartment, hesitates, hoping the man will tu the corner in the corridor. Instead, he stops at the apar just opposite. He begins fumbling in his pocket for his k He looks at Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: smiling at him feebly.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The man spread change and an assortment of junk on the pa of his hand as he searches for his key. Impatiently, Mela watches him. Making a decision, she puts the birdcage dow before the door to apartment 3B, and then opens her purse

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE'S GLOVED HAND
dialogues.text: reaching into the purse for a white envelope.

dialogues.speaker: THE FACE OF THE ENVELOPE
dialogues.text: written there in Melanie's handwriting: MR. MITCHELL BREN

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she props the envelope against the cage, and then hurr goes down the hallway, intent on retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss...?  She stops, distressed.

dialogues.speaker: THE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: the man at the one end, key in his hand; Melanie at the o end, near the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that for Mitch Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. She presses button for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't be back until Monday. I  mean, if those birds are for him....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I don't think you should leave  them in the hall, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trapped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I... The elevator doors open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where did he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodega Bay. He goes up there every  weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bodega Bay? Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on the coast. About sixty miles  north of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty... (her face falls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About an hour and a half on the  freeway. Or two if you take the coast  highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hold the birds for him, but I'm  going away myself. Someone's got to  feed them, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in utter despair now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, someone's got to feed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm awfully sorry. He puts the key into his lock, opens the door, and goes  inside. The door closes. Melanie is alone in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: exasperated. She looks at the open elevator. She turns to look at the birds.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOVEBIRDS
dialogues.text: in their cage outside the apartment door, CHATTERING.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: surrendering with a gesture of resignation. She walks dow the hall, picks up envelope and puts it in her purse, pic up the bird cage, carries it back to the elevator. The bi are COOING and CHIRPING madly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up! And she steps into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE'S OPEN CAR
dialogues.text: on the coast highway. It is a spectacularly beautiful day with a cloudless blue sky. The montage of SHOTS that foll should alternate between the winding, twisting road and t ocean below, and CLOSEUPS of Melanie driving with the cag birds on the seat beside her. The last shot should be a F SHOT of the car rounding a particularly sharp curve.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She turns wheel forcefully.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOVEBIRDS
dialogues.text: in the cage as the car rounds the bend. They lean to one  side as the car turns, come up straight again as the car  rounds the curve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car approaching Bodega Bay seen high up.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: at the wheel, she glances out toward the bay.

dialogues.speaker: A CLUSTER OF BUILDINGS AT WATERFRONT
dialogues.text: ahead, through the windshield as the car approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: behind the wheel, leaning forward slightly for a look at town.

dialogues.speaker: DOCKS ON LEFT
dialogues.text: through the windshield as Melanie slows her speed.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: behind wheel.

dialogues.speaker: STORES
dialogues.text: on right of the road as Melanie enters the town. SLOW PAN matching car's cruise past BAKERY, SHOE REPAIR, CLEANERS, RADIO AND TELEVISION.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: behind wheel.

dialogues.speaker: THE TIDES
dialogues.text: past the gas station and beyond to the parking area and t docks, continuing Melanie's slow observation of the place

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: studying the town. The car turns into road by gas station

dialogues.speaker: THE TOWN
dialogues.text: through the windshield. The car turns right. There is lif in the town now, fishermen crossing the road, women with  their hair in curlers, old ladies carrying shopping bags. This is Saturday morning, and the town -- such as it is - is alive with its inhabitants. We see them from Melanie's

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: pulling in, in front of the post office. Melanie opens th door and steps out. She is smartly dressed in a traveling suit and sweater. She looks up at the sign, and then walk quickly toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: enters post office.

dialogues.speaker: POSTAL CLERK
dialogues.text: behind cage as Melanie approaches it. He is busy filling a form of some kind, affixing stamps to it, etc. He does look up as she approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: through the bars of the cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a man named Mitchell  Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. He is still busy with his form, still does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here. Bodega Bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right across the bay there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? It seems as if the Clerk will not answer her. Suddenly, h leaves the window.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: through the bars, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: as she tries to peek through the bars to see where he's  vanished. A door to the left of the window opens, and the Clerk steps out. He walks a little distance as Melanie wa him, then stops, turns and looks at her surprised, as if  he'd expected her to be right behind him. He stands stock still, looking at her, saying nothing. She understands th that he wants her to follow him, and she catches up, neit speaking. They go to the front door. He opens it, looks a her, then looks out across the town and the bay. He exten his arm and points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See where I'm pointing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See them two big trees across there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the white house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where the Brenners live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Brenners? Mr. and Mrs. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, just Lydia and the two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Mitch and the little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. How do I get down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow the road straight through  town 'til it curves off on the left.   That'll take you right around the  bay to their front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there a back road I can take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. That's the road. Straight  through town, stay on your left,  right around the bay to the front  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I wanted to surprise them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to come right down the  road, where they could see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a surprise, you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmmm. (long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course, you could get yourself a  boat, cut right across the bay with  it. The Brenners got a little dock  there you could tie up at. If that's  what you wanted to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where would I get a boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down at the dock by the Tides  Restaurant. Ever handled an outboard  boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks back at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you want me to order one for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. He nods briefly and goes inside. Melanie looks across the bay.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: smiling. She gets a new idea. She reaches into her purse the envelope. She looks at the envelope, then tears it up and stuffs the torn envelope into her handbag. She turns  back toward the post office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Melanie approaches the Clerk's window. He is still bus still does not look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl's name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Brenner girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alice, I think. (he turns, shouts to  someone in rear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, what's the little Brenner  girl's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little Brenner girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Alice, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's Lois!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Alice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't positive, if that's  what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need her exact name, you see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That case, I tell you what you do.   You go straight through town 'til  you see a little hotel on your left  there. Not the motel, that's the  other end of town. This is the hotel.  Now you take a right turn there, you  got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the top of the hill, you'll see  the school and right behind it, the  church. You head for the school.   Now just past the school, you'll see  a little house with a red mail box.   That's where Annie Hayworth lives,  she's the school teacher. You ask  her about the little Brenner girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could save yourself a lot of trouble.  Her name's Alice for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I have the boat in about twenty  minutes? The Clerk nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much for the phone calls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing this aside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: grinning, as she makes for the door and EXITS.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: getting into the car and slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT (MATTE) - MELANIE'S CAR turning in school road.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE'S CAR
dialogues.text: passing the school and pulling up outside the teacher's h

dialogues.speaker: THE RED MAIL BOX
dialogues.text: with the name "Hayworth" on it. PULL BACK to reveal:

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: passing the mail box and going up the walk to the front d The house is a two-story frame with steps leading to the  front door. There are white curtains in every window of t house, and a sign in the window to the left of the doorwa advises, ROOM TO LET. Melanie rings the doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: waiting. She RINGS the bell again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's me?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: walking along the porch of the house. The walk in front o the house is lined with beautifully planted and cared-for flowers. ANNIE HAYWORTH comes round from the back of the  house as Melanie reaches the corner. She is a woman of th two, tall, big-boned, with a strong beautiful face.  Her  hair is disarrayed at the moment, and she is dressed for garden, wearing slacks and a loose-fitting sweater, and e stained gloves. But there is something about her, a feeli of expansive comfort, rather than sloppiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Hayworth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Melanie Daniels. I'm sorry to  bother you, but...

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: She is puzzled by Melanie who, exquisitely dressed and  groomed, seems singularly out of place in Bodega Bay. She studies her openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man at the post office sent me.   He said you'd know the name of the  little Brenner girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one who lives in the white house  across the bay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one. Cathy Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seemed sure it was either Alice  or Lois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why the mail in this town  never gets delivered to the right  place. (She takes out package  of cigarettes, offers  one to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you want to see Cathy about  something?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: taking cigarette, hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: studying her, thinking she understands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a friend of Mitch's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not really.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND ANNIE
dialogues.text: There is an awkwardness here. Annie wants to know more. S puffs on the cigarette, smiles, tries a friendly approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wanting a cigarette for  the past twenty minutes, but I  couldn't convince myself to stop.   This 'tilling of the soil' can get a  little compulsive, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lovely garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. It gives me something to  do with my spare time. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of spare time in Bodega  Bay. (another pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you plan on staying long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're leaving after you see Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... something like that. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't mean to sound so  mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's none of my business. There is a pause. Melanie, by her silence, affirms that i is none of Annie's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting out cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better get on my way. Thank you  very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. They begin walking toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still curious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you drive up from San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a nice drive. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that where you met Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's where everyone meets  him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she gets in behind the wheel. Annie's remark is not lo on her, and a quick look of sudden understanding crosses face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you sound a bit mysterious, Miss  Hayworth.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND ANNIE
dialogues.text: as Annie leans over the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I? (she shakes her head,  smiles wistfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm an open book, I'm afraid. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe a closed one. (she smiles again,  sees the lovebirds)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty. What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovebirds. Taking this as a further indication of Melanie's relation with Mitch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good luck, Miss Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She nods pleasantly, starts the car, pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: watching the car, a look of sad resignation on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: coming out of Brinkmeyer's General Store, carrying a smal paper bag, walking toward her car out front. The CAMERA  FOLLOWS her as she gets in. She opens her purse and reach in for the paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: HER HANDS
dialogues.text: She pulls out a birthday card from the paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: reaching into her purse again for a fountain pen. She uns the cap, braces the card on her closed purse.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARD
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday, the usual rhyming sentiments. The pen wri To Cathy

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE'S CAR
dialogues.text: crossing the highway down into the parking area behind th Tides, close to the docks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets out of the car and walks onto one of the docks, bird cage in her hand. Melanie approaches a waiting fishe She asks for her boat. The fisherman nods. He leads her t the dock and the waiting boat.  She gets into the outboar motorboat, the fisherman helping her. He hands down the  lovebirds in their cage.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: pulling away from the dock, heading across the bay.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: and the wide expanse of the bay, as it heads on a direct  course for the house on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another spectacular SHOT of the small boat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: coming head-on toward CAMERA, Melanie at the tiller. She  cuts the motor. The motor drifts to a stop. The bay is si except for the cry of the gulls. LONG SHOT - THE BRENNER HOUSE - MELANIE'S P.O.V. There is not a sign of activity as the boat drifts just a little closer. As Melanie watches, the front door opens a a woman comes out, walks to a red pickup truck, starts th engine. A little girl comes out of the house, goes to the truck, gets in. The woman shouts something to a man -- Mi Brenner, probably, though it is difficult to tell from th distance -- and he comes over to the truck. The truck grinds into gear, goes around the turnabout, an heads down the road away from the farm, a huge cloud of d behind it. The farm is still again. Mitch stands looking  after the truck for a moment, and then begins walking up  toward the barn in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching, biting her lip.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mitch reaching the barn and entering. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: watching, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Not a sign of life.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: picking up paddle from deck, beginning to paddle in towar dock.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOAT
dialogues.text: edging in toward the dock. Closer, closer, Melanie puts d the paddle. The boat drifts in.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: leaping ashore, tying up the boat, reaching down for the  cage. She climbs onto the dock and approaches the CAMERA  until she is in WAIST SHOT. The CAMERA STARTS to RECEDE i front of her as she walks forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The barn door closed, still no sign of Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Coming off the dock and onto the lawn, the CAMERA still  RETREATING in front of her. She makes her way carefully a the lawn, glancing toward the barn, carrying the bird cag

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: crossing the lawn, the CAMERA RETREATING in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: CAMERA RETREATING in front of her: Excitement and anticip on her face. She wets her lips. The CAMERA PANS WITH her she goes to front door and lets herself in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE BRENNER HOUSE ENTRY
dialogues.text: as the door opens. Melanie ENTERS quickly, and closes the door behind her. She glances around for a moment, getting her bearings. The house is silent.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: entering the dining room. Hastily, she puts the cage on t dinning room table, props the card up against it, then gl through the lace curtains on the dinning room window.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARN
dialogues.text: as before. EXT. BRENNER HOUSE - WAIST SHOT - MELANIE - MOVING P.O.V. as the front door opens and Melanie EMERGES. CAMERA PANS FOLLOWS her back down front walk. Melanie glances over he shoulder toward the barn. EXT. BARN - MOVING P.O.V. Mitch has not emerged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES MOVING on Melanie's back toward the end the dock. Melanie again glances over her shoulder toward barn. MOVING P.O.V. further along the dock toward the barn. Still no Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MELANIE
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES on her back for a short distance and STO as Melanie continues to the end of the dock and climbs in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA CONTINUES on her back for a short distance and STO as Melanie continues to the end of the dock and climbs in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Melanie as she paddles away from the dock.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: as she looks toward the house and barn. She starts to duc down. EXT. BARN - MELANIE'S P.O.V. as Mitch EMERGES from the barn and goes toward the house. goes INSIDE.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: peering over the stern of the boat. EXT. HOUSE - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch dashes OUT of the front door and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she watches Mitch. MELANIE'S P.O.V. as Mitch runs back INTO the house.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: peering over stern of the boat. MITCH - MELANIE'S P.O.V. as he EMERGES from the front door and raises binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he looks towards Melanie's boat through the binoculars The Bay is reflected in the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (THROUGH BINOCULARS)
dialogues.text: She is pulling at the cord which starts the motor. She si down and grabs the tiller. She looks back over her should as the boat moves away.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He is smiling with amused recognition; he lowers the  binoculars and dashes OUT OF FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, (PROCESS)
dialogues.text: The CAMERA IS MOVING WITH her as she looks toward Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Mitch is running for his car. The car door SLAMS. The ENG STARTS. The car practically leaps out of the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she watches the car race along the shore. LONG SHOT - CAR - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch's car racing along the shore.

dialogues.speaker: THREE QUARTER BACK LEFT
dialogues.text: She looks off RIGHT toward car. CAR - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch's car racing along the shore road, turns inland at  Keesport.

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT BACK
dialogues.text: Melanie looks CAMERA RIGHT, her eyes slowly turn CAMERA L CAR - MELANIE'S MOVING P.O.V. Mitch's car races past wrecked ferry boat.

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT BACK
dialogues.text: Her head continues to turn CAMERA LEFT. She looks off and sees: LONG SHOT - THE DOCK - MELANIE'S MOVING P.O.V. moves forward slower. Mitch drives onto dock, gets out of the car and stands waiting.

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT BACK
dialogues.text: partially posing for Mitch, her hair blowing in the wind, her head tilted back, a smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: GULL
dialogues.text: swooping down from UPPER LEFTHAND CORNER OF FRAME TO LOWE

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT BACK
dialogues.text: as gull strikes the back of her head. She recoils and loo up with shock and pain. GULL - MELANIE'S P.O.V. The gull soars away from LOWER RIGHTHAND corner of frame UPPER LEFT.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: reacting to the sudden attack and looking after receding  gull. Blood is starting down her temple from her hair.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as the boat comes closer. The boat drifts in toward a sec boat tied up at the dock. Mitch crosses the docked boat,  leaps into Melanie's boat.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH AND MELANIE
dialogues.text: in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the damndest thing I ever  saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What made it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It deliberately came down at you -- you're bleeding...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: a thin line of blood trickling from the cut on top of her head, down onto her forehead and cheek. She seems dazed. She shakes her head in answer to him, then touches the to of her head, looks at her bloody fingers, and then nods  weakly.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCK
dialogues.text: as they climb onto it. A fisherman standing by looks at  Melanie curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gull hit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what? The CAMERA FOLLOWS them as they walk across the parking a behind the Tides, and to the closest office. Mitch tries door knob. The door is locked.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he tries door of next office. It, too, is locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'd better go up to the  restaurant. They walk quickly up the slope to the Tides, establishing gas station across the road, the collection of stores  opposite, the cars pulling in and out. Mitch opens the do for her, and they ENTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a small neighborhood restaurant, with the feeling a local hangout. There are fishermen lounging at the bar, and a teenage boy playing one of the pinball machines. Tw ladies in housedresses, with their hair in curlers, are  sitting at one of the booths, having coffee. The rear wal of the restaurant is almost all window, looking out over bay and the parking area below. A television set over the bar is going. The shots and horsehoof beats of an old Wes movie should be HEARD muted throughout following.  DEKE  CARTER, who owns the restaurant with his wife, alternates his attention between serving his customers and watching Western. He looks up immediately when Mitch and Melanie E

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Mitch and Melanie coming over to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deke, have you got a first aid kit  back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instantly alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young woman cut herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I call the doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accepting the first  aid kit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's that serious.   You want to sit up here? Melanie climbs onto the stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut yourself outside, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop worrying, Deke. She was in a  boat. He is rummaging around in the kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a man trip and fall in the  parking lot once, sued me before I  could bat an eyelash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Miss Daniels is going  to sue anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doubtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're the lawyer. (goes to other end of  bar)

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as he unscrews cap from bottle of peroxide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some peroxide. I want to clean  out the cut. He pours peroxide onto a gauze pad and begins swabbing th cut. They are silent for several seconds. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. What are you doing in  Bodega Bay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you practice here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, San Francisco. What are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you'd like to see everyone  behind bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everyone, Miss Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only violators and practical jokers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. As he swabs cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you see the lovebirds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came all the way up here to bring  me those birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To bring your sister those birds.   You said it was her birthday.   Besides, I was coming up anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see a friend of mine. (she winces)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you please be careful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's your friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why... (pause, stymied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurting the only  name she knows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie. Annie Hayworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, small world. Annie  Hayworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing this was a  mistake)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the lie getting deeper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... we went to school together.   College.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you! Imagine that! How long will  you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few... just a day or two...  the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'll have to shave the hair.  Deke, have you got a razor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no you don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's still bleeding a little. Here,  let me put this on. He takes up a tiny Band-Aid and, tearing the gauze off, s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bend your head down. This little  Band-Aid won't show. He presses the tiny Band-Aid over the cut. Melanie takes mirror from her handbag and, bending her head down, looks it. She covers her hair over it as Mitch says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you came up to see Annie, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. (grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you came up to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I want to see you, of all  people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But it seems to me you  must have gone to a lot of trouble  to find out who I was, and where I  lived and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was no trouble at all. I simply  called my father's paper. Besides, I  was coming up here anyway, I already  told you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loathe you. You have no manners.   And you're arrogant and conceited  and... I wrote you a letter about  it, in fact, but I tore it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I still bleeding? She lowers her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't see a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say I like your seagulls  much, either. I come all the way up  here to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you were coming up anyway,  remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was! And all I get for my pains is  a... a... a hole in the head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right next to the one you already  had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Brenner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch? They turn toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA BRENNER
dialogues.text: closing the door behind her, coming toward the bar. She i woman in her late forties, attractive, wearing shirt, blo cardigan sweater, low heels. There is nothing agrarian-lo about her. She speaks with the quick tempo of the city  dweller, and there is lively inquiry in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I saw your car. What are  you doing in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising to greet her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to acknowledge a delivery. (grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, I'd like you to meet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie Daniels. Melanie, my mother.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Her eyebrows raising ever so slightly, not in displeasure but simply in enormous curiosity as she acknowledge the  introduction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Miss Daniels? (to Mitch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acknowledge a what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A delivery, Mother. Miss Daniels  brought some birds from San Francisco. Lydia thinks she understands. This is one of Mitch's San  Francisco chippies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Cathy. For her birthday. By the  way, where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across at Brinkmeyer's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Daniels is staying for the  weekend. In fact, I've already invited  her to dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning to him in surprise, beginning to shake her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, you did go to the trouble  of bringing up those birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I couldn't possibly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did say birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, lovebirds. We couldn't let you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (understanding  completely now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovebirds, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...get away without thanking you in  some small way. After all, you haven't  even met Cathy and you are staying  for the weekend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's settled. What time is  dinner, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven o'clock, same as usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pick you up, Miss Daniels.   Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With... with Annie, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, how stupid of me. A quarter  to seven, will that be all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie... Annie may have made other  plans. I'll have to see. Besides, I  can find my own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure now? You won't hire a  boat or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven o'clock then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: grinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be waiting. How's your head  now?

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Lydia looks at Mitch inquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with an overwarm  smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing, Mrs. Brenner. A gull  hit me, that's all. Lydia stares at her doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie is standing on the front steps, a paper bag in he hands. She rings the doorbell. The ROOM TO LET sign is st in the window. The door suddenly opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find her all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. There is a long awkward pause. Annie smiles expectantly a Melanie. Melanie seems hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sign. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could have the room  for a single night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd really hope to rent it  for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would appreciate it. I've tried  everywhere in town, and they're all  full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You can have it. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your bag? In the car? Melanie holds up the paper bag. Annie looks at it and the smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's utilitarian, I'll say that for  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just picked up some things for the  night at the general store. You see,  I hadn't planned on spending much  time here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. Did something unexpected  crop up? There is a moment where both women look at each other... When Melanie answers, it is abrupt and a trifle cold -- s is again telling Annie to mind her own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I use your phone? I'd like to  call home. There is another moment where Annie appraises Melanie's  attitude, and then accepts it. She suddenly smiles warmly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you come in then?  I was  just about to mix a martini. She is about to lead Melanie into the house when they bot hear a SOUND overhead. They turn to look skyward.

dialogues.speaker: A FLOCK OF LARGE BIRDS
dialogues.text: flying in beautiful precise formation against the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they ever stop migrating? But Melanie is watching the sky and the birds with a curi serious expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - THE APPROACH ROAD to the Brenner house. Melan car is driving along the shore. Behind her, the sky is st with sunset. There are gulls on the bay, cawing into the  silence.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: as it pulls into the Brenner yard.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: reaching up for the rear view mirror, tilting it to exami her lipstick, touching the edge of her mouth with one han She gets out of the car, CAMERA FOLLOWING her to the hous She climbs the porch steps, KNOCKS on the door. There is answer. Puzzled, she begins walking back into the yard. I the distance, she sees Mitch, Lydia and Cathy coming from behind the chicken sheds. She raises her arm in greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH, CATHY, LYDIA
dialogues.text: in the distance. Mitch and Cathy raise their arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! (she breaks into a  trot toward Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - CATHY as she approaches. She is an eleven-ye old child, clear-eyed, bright, uninhibited, wearing a shi and blouse, her hair cropped close to her head. She hesit for just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Daniels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? And Cathy flings herself into Melanie's arms, almost knoc her off her feet, hugging her fiercely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're beautiful! They're just what  I wanted! Is there a man and a woman?  I can't tell which is which.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Annie had no plans, huh? I'm  glad you came. Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Famished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner's just about ready. (explaining)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were out back looking at the  chickens. Something seems to be wrong  with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going toward house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with those  chickens, Mitch. I'm going to call  Fred Brinkmeyer right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they follow into  house)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what good that'll do. (aside to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chickens won't eat.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER HOUSE
dialogues.text: as they ENTER, CAMERA FOLLOWING them throughout into dini room where Lydia dials phone, talking to Mitch all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sold the feed to me, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caviat emptor, Mother. Let the buyer  beware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm simply quoting the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the law. Cathy, you can  start serving the soup. She has finished dialing now, is waiting while the phone  RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't take a minute, Miss Dan... (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Fred? This is Lydia Brenner.   I didn't interrupt your dinner, did

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, that feed you sold me is no  good. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chicken feed. The three bags I  brought.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: holding the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's just no good. The chickens  won't eat it. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're always hungry, Fred. I opened  one of the sacks when I got home,  and I poured it out for them, and  they wouldn't touch it. Now you know  chickens as well as I do, and when  they won't eat, there's just something  wrong with what they're being fed,  that's all. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're not fussy chickens. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? What's he got to do with it? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, I don't care how much feed you  sold him. My chickens... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did? Dan Fawcett? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This afternoon? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that only proves what I'm  saying. The feed you sold us is... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, I see. Uh-huh. Uh-huh.  Uh- huh. Maybe I ought to go over to see  him. You don't think there's something  going around, do you? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, never. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Fred, they don't seem sick at  all. They just won't eat. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. Mmmmm. Well, I'll try to get  over to Dan's farm.  Maybe he'll...  mmmmm... mmmmm... all right, Fred,  thanks. (she hangs up, puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: as Lydia comes to the table. Mitch and Melanie are sittin opposite each other in the center chairs. Cathy is servin the last bowl of soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got a call from Dan Fawcett a  little while ago. His chickens won't  eat, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what you said, Mom. Mr.   Brinkmeyer's feed is no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Cathy. He sold Mr. Fawcett a  different brand. (extremely worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think they're getting sick,  do you, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: her eyes troubled as she picks up her napkin.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: The meal is over. The lovebirds in their hanging cage hav been covered for the night. In the b.g. Mitch and Lydia a carrying the stacked dishes to the kitchen. In the f.g.   Cathy and Melanie are by a small upright piano. Melanie i playing a Debussy Arabesque: She picks up a cigarette fro the ashtray now and again to take a puff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't understand how you  knew I wanted lovebirds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she goes into  kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you knew Mitch in San Francisco,  is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch knows lots of people in San  Francisco. Of course, they're mostly  hoods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mom, he's the first to admit  it. (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spends half his day in the  detention cells at the Hall of  Justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a democracy, Cathy, everyone is  entitled to a fair trial. Your  brother's practice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, please, I know all the democracy  jazz. They're still hoods. (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a client now who shot his  wife in the head six times. Six times,  can you imagine it? (she starts for living  room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, even twice would be overdoing  it, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mitch as he carries  load of dishes out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he shoot her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was watching a ball game on  television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife changed the channel. He GOES INTO kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND CATHY
dialogues.text: Melanie interrupts her playing to take another puff at he cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is smoking fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have a puff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think your mother would like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little one.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND CATHY
dialogues.text: They both glance conspiratorially toward the kitchen.   Quickly, Melanie extends the cigarette. Quickly, Cathy ta a small puff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, it's just like air, isn't it? (determined)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I grow up, I'm gonna smoke like  a chimney! I'll be eleven tomorrow,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming to my party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. (seeing the child's  face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to get back to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching her hair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, of course I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like Bodega Bay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch likes it very much. He comes  up every weekend, you know, even  though he has his own apartment in  the city. He says San Francisco is  just an ant hill at the foot of a  bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it does get a little hectic  at times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do decide to come, don't say  I told you about it. It's supposed  to be a surprise party. Melanie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, they've got this whole  complicated thing figured out where  I'm going over to Michele's for the  afternoon, and Michele's mother is  going to say she has a headache and  would I mind very much if she took  me home. Then, when we get back here,  all of the kids'll jump out! (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you come? Won't you please  come?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: shaking her head, glancing toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA AND MITCH
dialogues.text: Mitch is helping her as she loads the dishwasher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a charming girl, isn't she,  Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And certainly pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you known her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. We met yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a bird shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was selling birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I only led her into believing I  believed she was... Mother, it's  really very complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she did buy the lovebirds and  then brought them all the way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, where did you go to law  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I suppose I'm just  naturally curious about a girl like  that. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very rich, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose so. Her father owns a big  newspaper in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd think he could manage to keep  her name out of print. She's always  mentioned in the columns, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is the one who jumped into that  fountain in Rome last summer, isn't  she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I'm old-fashioned. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was supposed to be very  warm there, Mitch, but... well...   actually... well, the newspaper said  she was naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's none of my business, of course,  but when you bring a girl like that  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can handle Melanie Daniels  by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (she sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as you know what you want,  Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what I want, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER LAWN
dialogues.text: as Mitch and Melanie cross it to her car. A wind is blowi off the water, and high fast clouds are scudding across t face of the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be able to find your way back,  won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I be seeing you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco's a long way from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in San Francisco five days a  week. With a lot of time on my hands.  I'd like to see you. (he grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could go swimming or  something. Mother tells me you like  to swim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does Mother know what I like to  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess she and I read the same gossip  columns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That. Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get  along very...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you're interested, I was  pushed into that fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without any clothes on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all my clothes on!  The newspaper  that ran the story happens to be a  rival of my father's paper.  Anything  they said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were just a poor, innocent victim  of circumstance, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but  the truth of that particular...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is you were running around  with a pretty wild crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...who didn't much care for propriety  or convention or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
