dialogues.text: ...the opinions of others, and you  went right along with them, isn't  that the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's the truth. But I was  pushed into that fountain, and that's  the truth, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Do you really know Annie  Hayworth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least, I didn't until I came up  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you didn't go to school together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you didn't come up here to see  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I was lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you really write a letter to me?   Or was that a lie, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think  you need those lovebirds, after all.   They may help your personality."  That's what it said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you tore it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it seemed stupid and foolish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you what happened in Rome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you expect me to believe...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn what you believe! Angrily she gets into the car, is about to slam the door  when Mitch catches it in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd still like to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it could be fun.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: pulling the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might have been good enough in  Rome last summer. But it's not good  enough now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you knew! I want to go  through life laughing and beautiful  and jumping into fountains naked!   Good night!

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: as it pulls away. Mitch yanks his hands back from the doo

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he watches the car leave.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: The car turns the bend and disappears. Empty road. Only t long line of telephone poles and wires and... something  strange on the wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attention caught by the poles and wires.

dialogues.speaker: THE WIRES
dialogues.text: Hundreds of birds sitting on them.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: standing and watching. A wind blows off the water. He shi suddenly, turns up his collar, and heads for the house.

dialogues.speaker: HAYWORTH
dialogues.text: In an easy chair, reading. She is wearing a robe and smok absorbed in her book. She turns when she hears the front  DOOR OPENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Daniels? Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Annie rises to greet her. As Melanie ENTERS THE SHOT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. (seeing her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong? Is that cut  beginning to bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not the cut that's bothering  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like some brandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have some, I'd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it, sit down, Miss Daniels.   Do you want a sweater or something?   A quilt? As Annie gets the brandy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you call me Melanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (she smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT - MELANIE sitting, tucking her legs up under he She is disturbed by her conversation with Mitch and, in f by the way this entire trip has worked out. Annie brings the glass of brandy, and she takes it gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting opposite her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It gets a little chilly here at night  sometimes. Especially if you're over  near the bay. Melanie nods and sips at the brandy. There is a long paus

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how'd your evening go? Melanie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you meet Lydia? Melanie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or would you rather I changed the  subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a tired smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like our little hamlet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I despise it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't suppose it offers much  to the casual visitor. Unless you're  thrilled by a collection of shacks  on a hillside. It takes a while to  get used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you from originally, Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you happen to come here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, someone invited me up for the  weekend a long time ago. There is an awkward pause. Annie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I see no reason for being coy  about this. It was Mitch Brenner. Melanie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you knew that, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suspected as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You needn't worry. It's over and  done with. A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie -- there's nothing between  Mitch and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there? (she shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there isn't. Maybe there's  never anything between Mitch and any  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll have some of that, too. (she pours brandy,  drinks, sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was seeing quite a lot of him in  San Francisco, you know. (she smiles weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, one weekend, he asked me  up to meet Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years ago. Of course, that was  shortly after his father died.  Things  may be different now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Lydia. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she seem a trifle distant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe it isn't different at  all. You know, her attitude nearly  drove me crazy. I simply couldn't  understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I got back to San Francisco I  spent days trying to figure out just  what I'd done to displease her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what had you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! I simply existed. So what  was the answer? A jealous woman,  right? A clinging possessive mother. (she shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. With all due respect to  Oedipus, I don't think that was the  case at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia liked me, you see. That was  the strange part of it. In fact, now  that I'm no longer a threat, we're  very good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did she object to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she was afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid you'd take Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid I'd give Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid of any woman who'd give Mitch  the only thing Lydia can give him -- love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, that adds up to a jealous,  possessive woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. She's not afraid  of losing her son, you see.  She's  only afraid of being abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone ought to tell her she'd be  gaining a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She already has a daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Mitch? Didn't he have  anything to say about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand his position. He  went through a lot with Lydia after  his father died. He didn't want to  risk going through it all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it ended. Not immediately, of  course. I went back to San Francisco,  and I still saw Mitch every now and  then... but we both knew it was  finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing here in Bodega  Bay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get straight to the point, don't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's all right, I don't mind.   I came up here for two reasons. To  begin with, I was bored with my job  in San Francisco. I was teaching at  a private school there... well, you  know, you probably went to one  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you know. Little girls in brown  beanies. Deadly. Here I have a life.  I'll go into that classroom on Monday  morning, and I'll look out at twenty- five upturned little faces, and each  of them will be saying, 'Yes, please  give me what you have.' (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll give them what I have. I  haven't got very much, but I'll give  them every ounce of it. To me, that's  very important. It makes me want to  stay alive for a long long time. (she sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the first reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be near Mitch. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was over, and I knew it, but I  wanted to be near him, anyway. (she smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I still like him a hell of  a lot. That's rare, I think. I don't  want to lose his friendship... ever. There is a moment of silence. Into the silence, the TELEP shrills. Annie hesitates a moment, and then goes to answe it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?  Oh, hello. No, no, I wasn't  asleep. What is it? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, just a little while ago. Sure,  hold on. (she turns to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mitch. For you.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND ANNIE
dialogues.text: as they stare at each other across the room, Melanie  hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waiting. Melanie rises and goes to the phone. The CAMERA FOLLOWS A to the wing chair in the foreground and stays on her  throughout following, recording her reactions as Melanie  talks to Mitch in the background. Annie is not devastated by this call, and yet there is a  wistfulness to her expression as she realizes she may fin and irrevocably be losing Mitch to another girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at phone; coolly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, this is Melanie. Fine,  thank you. No, no trouble at all.  I  simply followed the road. It's a  very bright night. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh. Well, there's no need to  apologize. I can understand... (pause; she listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (she listens again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. No, I'm not  angry. (she listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't. I'm afraid I have to get  back to San Francisco. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't want to disappoint  Cathy, but... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. (she is warming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Well, if you really... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Yes, I'll be there. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mitch. She hangs up and looks at Annie in embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to go to Cathy's party  tomorrow afternoon. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be going, too, to help out. It  should be fun, Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems so pointless. (she sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll go to sleep. This has  been a busy day. (picking up her paper  bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My luggage. She smiles, takes out a flowered muumuu, holds it up to A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty. Did you get that at  Brinkmeyer's? Melanie nods and drapes the muumuu over her arm. She is s for a moment, pensive. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I should go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really up to Lydia, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind Lydia. Do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go. The room is silent. Melanie nods, slowly, and then smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Annie. Suddenly, into the silence, comes a THUMP at the door,  startling them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can that be at this hour? (she walks to door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it? (no answer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is someone there? Melanie goes to stand beside Annie. Puzzled, Annie unlock the door, and then opens it. She looks out into the night There is nothing but the SOUND of the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the emptiness  outside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the ground)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sympathetically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh. Oh, the poor thing. He probably  lost his way in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: who stares at the dead bird as Annie stoops to pick it up And then, slowly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... it isn't dark, Annie.  There's  a full moon.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND ANNIE
dialogues.text: as Annie, stooping, looks up at her. On their puzzlement consternation:

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: HIGH SHOT - THE BRENNER HOUSE The place is decorated with balloons strung from the house to various points on the l The children, in party clothes, with their parents, are  clustered around a long folding table upon which are  sandwiches, ice cream and soft drinks. The parents are ei helping the children to more or telling them they are hav too much. There is a general SOUND of kid's CHATTER and  LAUGHTER. Coming up the sloping path, away from the party are Melanie and Mitch. The CAMERA PANS them UP the slope away from the party in background. As they turn the hairp bend of the slope, and come up toward the CAMERA, we see entrance of the harbor and the Pacific in the background. The CAMERA PANS them as they come near to us and, once mo the party is in the background. Mitch and Melanie pass th CAMERA out to the left.

dialogues.speaker: THE TOP OF THE DUNES
dialogues.text: Melanie and Mitch come INTO the picture from the right an stand against the sky. Mitch takes a martini shaker from of his pockets, and two glasses from the other. He hands of the glasses to Melanie, and then pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really shouldn't have any more.   I'm a little tipsy already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to get you to stay for  dinner. We're going to have a lot of  roast left over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't possibly. I have to get  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a shrug)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in this? Nitro-glycerin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have to rush off? What's  so important in San Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I have to get to work tomorrow  morning, for one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sipping at the martini)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have several jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do different things on different  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Mondays and Wednesdays, I work  for the Travelers' Aid. At the  airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helping travelers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She hesitates for a moment, thinking. She has never reall considered before what she does with her time, and now th she is accounting for it, it sounds a little meaningless unimportant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on Tuesdays, I take a course in  General Semantics at Berkeley.  That's  not a job, of course. I just take it  because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Thursdays and Fridays?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Thursdays I have my meeting and  lunch. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm chairman of a group that's sending  a little Korean boy through school.   We plan how to raise funds and...  things like that. (she shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Fridays? What do you do then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (she smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go to bird shops on Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what I was doing in that  shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an aunt, you see. Aunt Tessa.  She's seventy years old, and veddy  prim and strait-laced. (she does an imitation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming back from Europe at the  end of the month, and I'm going to  give her a myna bird that'll talk to  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetiously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll think me very bold, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, tell me. She leans over and whispers in his ear. They both burst o LAUGHTER. But then suddenly, a very serious look comes in Melanie's face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: serious, introspective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's silly, isn't it?  Teaching a  bird to shock my aunt. That's just  silly and childish. (slight pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I ought to go join the other  children.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as she moves abruptly away from him, and starts toward wh the children have begun playing Blind Man's Bluff. Mitch  stares after her for a moment, moved by this sudden glimp of character, and then follows her down the dune. The chi are all in a circle. Annie is busy changing the blindfold from Michele to Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is now on the lawn POINTING UP toward dunes. W see Mitch and Melanie descending. They are coming down by way of a short cut and are not on the zig-zag path. As th reach the lawn they move along the side of it at the foot the dunes. They are absorbed in each other. The CAMERA PA OFF them and BRING INTO the picture Annie, surrounded by children. She is in the act of changing the blindfold fro Michele to Cathy. She hands Michele her glasses back.  Du this, and while she is putting the blindfold round the ey of Cathy, she is looking to her right and obviously is  watching Mitch and Melanie. MITCH AND MELANIE - ANNIE'S P.O.V.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES A LITTLE to her left (CAMERA RIGHT). At this moment, in the background, Lydia is emerging with the bir cake. The candles on it are unlit. Lydia immediately also catches sight of Mitch and Melanie and she slows up somew as she walks to the long table, her eyes still on the cou During this we see Annie in the foreground sending Cathy  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then, here we go. (she spins her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once! (she spins her again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twice! (she spins her again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three! Go get 'em, Cathy! She says all this while still looking toward the couple. turns her head away from the couple with a new expression her face. She twists completely around to look at Lydia a though she were wondering if Lydia sees what she sees.   Suddenly we HEAR a little boy's voice crying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! Look! Annie swings round and the CAMERA RUSHES INTO her face as she looks up. LONG SHOT - ANNIE'S P.O.V. A gull is swooping down.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: as she changes her tactics, stops dead, and then cautious reaches out in front of her at the air. The gull suddenly swoops at her, hitting her shoulder. She whirls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No touching allowed! She almost falls.

dialogues.speaker: THE GULL
dialogues.text: seen from Cathy's position. He flies off, cycles and then returns.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: reacting to gull. She turns her head back to Cathy.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: reacting to the gull hitting Cathy. They start towards Ca

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: with Cathy and the children around. The CAMERA PANS DOWN she ducks with two gulls swooping by.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: hurriedly putting the cake onto the table. She rushes rou to the front of it. FULL SHOT - ANNIE - LYDIA'S P.O.V. Annie rising from the ground. Cathy and the other childre are running in the background.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: reacting to two more gulls diving. FULL SHOT - TWO GULLS - LYDIA'S P.O.V. diving toward the children.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: She starts to run out CAMERA RIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA REACHES CATHY
dialogues.text: She pushes her to the ground as a gull attacks.

dialogues.speaker: TWO MOTHERS
dialogues.text: as a gull swoops between them.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: coming out of the house with a broom.

dialogues.speaker: TWO GULLS
dialogues.text: swooping down at the children's heads.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: swinging at gull and missing.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: running toward bank. Gull swooping after him.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: falling forward against the bank as the gull smashes into him.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: running to the injured boy, who is lying against the bank

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE, MITCH AND LITTLE BOY
dialogues.text: They look up.

dialogues.speaker: THE GULLS
dialogues.text: against the sky, flying away in formation.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: about to swing with the broom again, but the birds are no longer there. A puzzled look crosses his face. He turns t Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the darnest thing thing I've  ever seen in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAWN
dialogues.text: as the children begin drifting back toward the table and cake. There is the curious feeling of lighting having str very close by without having injured anyone. All that  adrenaline has boiled up, and now it has no place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... well, is everyone all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a small boy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he got a little scratch,  Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see them? They were hawks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were bigger than hawks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, they were only seagulls. And then the meaning of what she has just said strikes he and she remembers the bird hitting her door the night bef

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE AND MELANIE
dialogues.text: as Annie turns to look at her and they exchange a silent  meaningful glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have been after the food,  Mother. They all turn toward the table.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: eyes narrowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to restore  order)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're gone now, so... so  let's... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was 'it?' You were 'it,' weren't  you, Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I be 'it,' Miss Hayworth?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as Annie and the children begin the game behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look a little shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I am. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, is... Mitch, this isn't usual,  is it? The gull yesterday when I was  in the boat, and the one last night  at Annie's, and now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gull smashed into Annie's front  door. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch... what's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Melanie. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, do you have to go back to  Annie's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have my things in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stay and have something to eat  before you start back. I'd feel a  lot better.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She nods, and then looks up at the sky. Suddenly she shud

dialogues.speaker: MITCH'S HANDS
dialogues.text: He is slicing the leftover roast beef.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: putting the meat onto plate, turning over his shoulder to call into living room. The lovebirds in their cage are ma a terrible racket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want some mustard with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't Annie stay for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said something about having to  get home to take a call from her  mother back East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Where d'you want the coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it into the living room, would  you, hon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the birds)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with them? Lydia turns from a side table, where she is cutting some  French bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with all the birds? She covers the cage. Under the cover, the birds are still tweeting madly. Lydia stares at the covered cage for a mo and then signs heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up with the rest, Mitch. I'm  sure Miss Daniels wants to get on  her way. As she moves into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you ought to stay the night,  Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: a sharp look at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: pouring coffee into the cups set on coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got an extra room upstairs and  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming in with two  plates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That road can be a bad one at night,  Melanie. (he picks up coffee  cup, hands it to  Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are now all eating with plates on their knees - buff style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I go across to Santa Rosa I'll  come onto the freeway much earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up a cup)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and the freeway's well-lighted,  isn't it, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but she'll be hitting all that  traffic going back to San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you put the cover on that cage,  Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just listen to them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some cream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it. She reaches over for the cream pitcher. Her eye is caught something in the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking curiously.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIREPLACE
dialogues.text: a single swift is sitting on the hearth.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning to Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: THE FIREPLACE
dialogues.text: as dozens of swifts begin pouring from the opening.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: frightened now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch!

dialogues.speaker: THE FIREPLACE
dialogues.text: hundreds of birds pouring into the room.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: shrieking in terror, dropping her coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: full of birds, swooping, diving. Mitch runs to the door,  throws it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outside! Run! (he turns toward Lydia)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - LYDIA in terror, surrounded by birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: wrenching the cloth from the coffee table, cups, coffee p sugar bowl, creamer falling to the floor as he swings the cloth at the birds.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: covering her face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: reaching for small fireplace broom.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: shrieking as the birds dive at her face.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: realizing it's impossible to run. They must stay and figh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy, get some matches!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: running for the kitchen. Birds swooping after her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: swinging the fireplace broom.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: rushing to the fireplace. He is almost knocked over by bi coming out of the opening. He stuffs paper under the logs already in place there.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: She lets out a horrified scream. There are birds flutteri in her hair, caught there.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: swinging the broom, covered with birds.

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE ON THE WALL
dialogues.text: (an enlargement of a photograph of Cathy, smiling.) As a  bird flutters against it.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: running into the room, covering her face with bent arm,  rushing to Mitch with the box of matches.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: taking the matches. He lights one. A bird hits his arm. H drops the match. He lights another one.

dialogues.speaker: THE MATCH
dialogues.text: falling onto the paper in the fireplace. It flickers for moment, then catches. Birds are still pouring out, past t paper beginning to catch.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER WINDOW PANE
dialogues.text: as a bird crashes through it.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: rushing to Lydia, swinging the cloth at her head. She is  hysterics now, BABBLING. The SHRIEK of the birds is a wil cacophony.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRE
dialogues.text: blazing.

dialogues.speaker: A BIRD
dialogues.text: swooping out of the fireplace, its wings aflame.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: less birds in the air now, the single flaming bird flying toward the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAPES
dialogues.text: as the flaming bird lands on them.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRAPES
dialogues.text: catching fire.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: swinging the broom wildly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch! The curtains!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: turning, seeing, his eyes opening wide.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: ripping at the flaming curtain. He throws it to the floor begins stamping on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's working! The fire's working!

dialogues.speaker: THE FIREPLACE
dialogues.text: only the blazing fire. No more birds entering.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOWS
dialogues.text: birds bursting through the panes, leaving.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she beats away another bird.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE BROKEN WINDOWS
dialogues.text: the birds leaving en masse now.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: A shambles. Windows broken, furniture knocked over, pictu askew, the floor covered with birds and broken glass. In corner of the room, Lydia crouches with her hands coverin her face, sobbing. The burnt curtain is still smoldering. Mitch is covered with soot. Melanie puts down the broom  wearily. The attack is over.

dialogues.speaker: A HAND
dialogues.text: reaching down to pick up a dead bird.

dialogues.speaker: AL MALONE, THE DEPUTY
dialogues.text: a plain man with a limited intelligence, used to giving o speeding tickets or warning drunks. He holds the bird on palm of his hand, looks at it steadily, nodding all the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a chimney swift, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know what it is, Al.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Lydia is huddled in one of the easy chairs, still in shoc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, these birds live in chimneys,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by the thousands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I gotta admit this is peculiar. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a light burning or  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but the curtains were drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause sometimes birds are attracted  by light, you know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is a peculiar thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do about it,  Al?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I get you, Mitch. Do  about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (he feels a little  foolish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... these birds attacked us.

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: slight disbelief on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's more likely, they got in the  room and was just panicked, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still a little  hesitant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll grant you a bird'll  panic in an enclosed room. But, they  didn't just get in. They came in!  Right down that chimney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make sense  of this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife found a bird in the back  seat of her car once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't know how he got in there.   Had a broken leg, turned out. Just  fluttering all around there. (he shrugs again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These birds were...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm trying to say, Mitch, is  these things happen sometimes, you  know? Ain't much we can do about it. (he shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him about the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. We had a party here  this afternoon for Cathy. Her  birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yeah. (he grins)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is she now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven. In the middle of the party,  some gulls came down at the children.  And Miss Daniels was attacked by a  gull just yesterday after...

dialogues.speaker: MALONE
dialogues.text: considering this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the kids bothering them or  something? 'Cause sometimes they'll  do that, you know. If you make any  kind of disturbance near them, they'll  just come after you. I seen that  plenty of times myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children were playing a game,  Al. Those gulls attacked without...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Lydia, 'attack' is a pretty  strong word, don't you think? I mean,  birds just don't go around attacking  people without no reason, you know  what I mean? The kids just probably  scared them, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These birds attacked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what would you like me to do,  Lydia? Put out a pick up and hold on  any suspicious birds in the area? (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that'd be pretty silly, wouldn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this room look silly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you got quite a mess here, I'll  admit that. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you oughta put some screening  on top of your chimney (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems a little pointless, though.   Freak accident like this wouldn't  happen again in a million years. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some help cleaning up?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it myself.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: giving a small moan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Cathy up to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: observing, making no comment.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: putting her arm around Cathy's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get my things from the car. Do  you want to walk with me, Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH AND MALONE
dialogues.text: as Cathy and Melanie go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if there's anything else I can  do, Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Al. We'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Lydia. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is peculiar, I got to say that  for it. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: It is silent. Mitch looks across at Lydia who sits as sti as a stone in her chair. The door closes gently on a note utter helplessness.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Melanie has just gotten out of bed. She is wearing the ra unsophisticated nightdress she brought at the store.  Her hair is loose. She wears no makeup. She is bent over a  lavatory which has been installed in the bedroom. She is  busily brushing her teeth. Her head half turns as she HEA VOICES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch! Mitch! Mitch, I'm going to  drop Cathy off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll probably drive over to the  Fawcett farm. Do you need anything  in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Melanie finished brushing her teeth. She goes to the wind and looks out. Outside, we HEAR the SOUND of the pickup t starting. FULL SHOT - THE YARD BELOW - MELANIE'S P.O.V. as Cathy, carrying her schoolbooks, runs to the pickup tr and climbs in. The truck moves out of the yard and down t road. It turns the bend, and moves out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning from the window. She goes to the bedroom door, CA FOLLOWING. She opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch? There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: coming down the steps from the attic room. The house is e The CAMERA FOLLOWS her into the dining room, where she st at the cage of lovebirds, bends down to them with a smile her face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND THE BIRDS
dialogues.text: She smiles and pokes her finger into the cage. The birds  TWEET at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chee-chee-chee-chee-chee.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: leaving the cage. She walks to the sideboard upon which i an electric coffee percolator which is plugged into the w She feels it with her hand. It is hot. She pours a cup, t peers out of the side window. LONG SHOT - MELANIE'S P.O.V. Mitch on the shore, working with a rake in his hands. A t column of smoke is climbing the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: carrying the cup of coffee. She sets it down for a moment put on her fur coat, which is hanging on the hall stand. picks up the cup again, walks to the front door and EXITS

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: coming out of the house and into the garden, carrying the cup of coffee. It is a beautiful day. She sips at her cof and then breathes deeply of the air.

dialogues.speaker: HER FACE
dialogues.text: fresh, rested. There is a contentment in her which we hav not seen before. She looks off toward the shore.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: on the shore, working with the rake. The thin column of s is climbing the sky.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She turns her attention away from Mitch, and walks to the end of the garden toward the shore. A wind is blowing off the water, moving white puffs of cloud swiftly across the sky, whipping the full short shirt of muumuu about her le as she walks. She stands there silhouetted against the sk for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Melanie scans the horizon. There isn't a bird anywhere sight. The day is still and clear, but somehow ominous in its silence. Her gaze comes to rest on Mitch and the thin column of smoke again. In the distance, Mitch sees her an raises his arm in greeting. She waves back at him. He put the rake down and begins walking toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: There is anticipation on her face now. She watches Mitch  coming toward her, her eyes glowing.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: closer to the house now.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: waiting, anticipating.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He stops, looks at her, and then turns toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as first surprised, and then puzzled. The back screen DOO CLATTERS shut off screen. A small hurt look crosses her f

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she turns away from the house and begins walking in th garden, sipping idly at her coffee. A screen DOOR CLATTER again. She turns. Mitch is coming out of the house, from the front door, we a different shirt, buttoning it as he walks to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to change my shirt. Melanie is uncomprehending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It smelled of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to believe anything at all  happened yesterday, isn't it? It's  so beautiful and still now. (pause; then sagely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've got it all figured out,  by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (secretively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an uprising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, of birds. Mitch grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It all started several months ago  with a peasant sparrow up in the  hills, a malcontent. He went around  telling all the other sparrows that  human beings weren't fit to rule  this planet, preaching wherever anyone  would listen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing a beard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, he had to have a  beard! 'Birds of the world, unite!'  he kept saying, over and over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they united.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at first. Oh yes, a few sparrows  out for kicks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they'll go along with anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. But eventually, even the more  serious-minded birds began to listen.   "Why should humans rule?" they asked themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should we submit ourselves to  their domination?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear, hear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all the while, that sparrow was  getting in his little messages.   Birds of the world, unite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take wing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have nothing to lose but your  feathers. They both burst out laughing, then fall into silence, the laugh again and finally are silent. The garden is deathly still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attempting to be  serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it was, probably...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're probably hungry, that's all.   This was a bad summer. They eat  berries and... and nuts, you know,  and the hills are all burned out, so  they're probably searching for food  wherever they can get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With my little sparrow leading team. She laughs, and Mitch joins her, but it is hollow this ti Like children who have told themselves a too realistic ho story, they are becoming a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so damn quiet out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like that yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the gulls attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hadn't thought of that. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then the swifts came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes you feel as if they're...  they're waiting or... resting...  or....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to make it  light again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're having a meeting, Melanie.  Your sparrow is standing on a soap  box and...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: her face dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...waving his little wings... His voice trails. His face becomes serious, too. Again, t garden is silent.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: her face set and grim, her eyes serious, her words coming slowly and with the chill of horror on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were angry, Mitch. They came  out of the chimney in fury. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had the feeling they wanted each  and every one of us dead.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: He takes her in his arms suddenly, to comfort her. She go to him longingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie, Melanie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm frightened, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm frightened and confused and I...  I think I want to go back to San  Francisco where there are buildings  and... and concrete and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...everything I know. She looks up at him suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh damn it, why did you have to walk  into that shop? They kiss suddenly and fiercely. On their kiss,

dialogues.speaker: THE RED PICKUP TRUCK
dialogues.text: Lydia at the wheel, pulling into the Fawcett farm, the na of the farm clearly visible on a painted arch over the ga Lydia gets out of the truck and walks to the front door. knocks. There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? She comes down off the steps, the CAMERA FOLLOWING, back little away from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? There is no answer. She shades her eyes and looks out ove the fields.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARNYARD
dialogues.text: as Lydia crosses to a fence and cups her hands to her mou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, there!

dialogues.speaker: THE FARMHAND
dialogues.text: He stops the tractor, turns toward Lydia, shading his eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mr. Fawcett home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so, ma'm. His missus is in  Santa Cruz, but he ought to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen him this morning?

dialogues.speaker: THE FARMHAND FARMHAND
dialogues.text: No, ma'm. I reckon he's in there, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: as she crosses the barnyard again. There are several chic scurrying about. She walks closer to them, sees an open b of feed lying against the fence.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: getting an idea.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: reaching into the bag of feed. She scatters some on the  ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, chick, chick, chick, chick.   Here, chick, chick, chick, chick.

dialogues.speaker: A CHICKEN
dialogues.text: He struts up to the scattered grain.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: watching him.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHICKEN
dialogues.text: He seems to be examining the feed. Then he turns away fro it and struts off.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: a small knowledgeable nod of her head. The chicken's reac strengthens her determination to talk to Fawcett.  She tu

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: approaching the front door again. She knocks. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? She backs away from the house again. The barnyard is sile In the distance, we can HEAR the SOUND of the tractor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? Are you home? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: a little annoyed. She glances at the ground floor window  closest to the door.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: A small pane of glass is broken.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: going to the front door, trying the knob.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: The door opening ahead of her as she pokes her head into house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? The house is still and silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Lydia comes in. We can see the living room off to the  right, but it looks normal and untouched. Lydia turns to left and looks down a long corridor. FULL SHOT - THE CORRIDOR - LYDIA'S P.O.V. a door at the end of it is partially ajar, spilling artif light into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: a little troubled. She seems deciding whether or not she  should leave. A determined look comes over her face. FULL SHOT - THE CORRIDOR - LYDIA'S P.O.V. as she walks down it slowly toward the open door at the  opposite end. Outside the door, she pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan? Are you in there? No answer. Lydia puts out her hand, slowly begins showing the door open.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: coming into the room. Her eyes begin to take in the room. SLOW PAN OF THE ROOM - LYDIA'S P.O.V. starting to the right of the doorway as she enters and  continuing a little below eye level, the CAMERA PICKS OUT standing floor lamp, the shade dangling, but the light st burning; a picture hanging askew on the wall, its glass  shattered; the window to the left of the picture, every p of glass shattered; a dresser with two stuffed birds on i top; both birds have been badly damaged, the stuffing rip out of them, the head of one hanging at a crooked near  decapitated angle; the window to the left of the dresser, all the panes shattered. The level of the CAMERA DESCENDS and begins a SLOW PAN of the floor. It PICKS OUT broken g continues its PAN to SHOW scattered feathers, continues i PAN to SHOW a broom, feathers caught in the straw, a sing bedroom slipper, continues to SHOW a pair of legs in paja one foot bare, the other slippered, and then immediately

dialogues.speaker: DAN FAWCETT
dialogues.text: His face. Covered with blood, the eyes missing from their empty staring sockets.  Immediately

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: a terrified scream erupting from her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: turning and running for the door. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her an unbroken headlong flight, the scream continuing as if is incapable of stopping it, as she stumbles, runs, trips her way down the corridor and bursts out of the house, st screaming, into the pickup truck. The engine starts, she  backs the truck out at breakneck speed and hits the highw

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: at the wheel, her face stamped with terror, her eyes wide

dialogues.speaker: THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: at breakneck speed, negotiating the severe curves on the  highway. It almost hits a small car coming from the oppos direction, swerves, screeches around the curve.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: behind the wheel, unmindful of anything but flight.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: through the windshield, blurring past. She turns the bend leading to the house. For an instant, through the windshi there is a quick glimpse of Melanie and Mitch in embrace the garden. Then the tires shriek, and the truck turns an barrels into the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: alarmed as he runs out of the garden and toward the truck just as it jerks to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: through the truck as he pulls open the door opposite Lydi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he sees his mother.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: slumped on the wheel of the car, her head on her arms,  sobbing. On her sobs...

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: at the kitchen stove, taking a kettle of tea from the bur She pours it into a cup, puts the cup on a tray already s with sugar and creamer. She looks up as Mitch comes into kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Al on the phone. He wants  me to meet him out at the Fawcett  place. Says some detectives from  Santa Rosa'll be there in a little  while. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you be all right here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I was just taking her in some  tea. He goes to her, puts his arms around her from behind, kis her hair. But she turns in his arms suddenly and clings t him fiercely, and then buries her head in his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful. Please. She walks him to the door. At the door, they kiss -- a lo full kiss.

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: as Mitch goes out. Melanie looks after him for a moment, then picks up the tray. Outside, we HEAR the SOUND of his car starting. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Melanie out of the kitch through the dining room, and to one of the bedroom doors the other side of the house. Gently, she KNOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: This is Lydia's room, and cluttered with the mementos of life no longer valid.  There are photographs of her dead  husband, souvenirs of trips taken together, bric-a-brac o Mitch's childhood. Under it all, there is a distinct  femininity. She sits up in bed as Melanie enters, bearing the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's me, Mrs. Brenner. I thought  you might like some tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. There is a long silence as Melanie puts the tray on the b arranges the pillows behind Lydia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al Malone wanted him out at the  Fawcett farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Didn't Al believe my story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was calling from the farm, Mrs.   Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have. He sent for the Santa  Rosa police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good will they do? She sips at the tea. There is a long awkward pause. Melan walks to the window and looks out over the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Cathy's all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy. At the school.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: at the window, her face turned away from Lydia. Her expre clearly shows that she doesn't know whether Cathy is all  right. But when she turns to Lydia, there is a comforting smile on her face, and her voice is soothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm sure she's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I sound foolish to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep seeing Dan Fawcett's face. (she shudders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have such big windows at the  school. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the windows were broken. In Dan's  bedroom. All the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to think of that, Mrs.   Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I were a stronger person.   There is a long awkward silence. She  sips at her tea reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my husband four years ago,  you know. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's odd how you depend on someone  for strength, and then suddenly all  the strength is gone, and you're  alone. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to relax some time. I'd  love to be able to sleep. (pause; the worried  look again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Cathy's all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie's there. She'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not this way, you know. Not  usually. I don't fuss and fret over  my children. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Frank died... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, he knew the children, he  really knew them. He had the knack  of being able to enter into their  world, of becoming a part of them.   That's a rare talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could be that way. There is another silence. A curious thing is happening in this room. Lydia, for perhaps the first time since her  husband's death, is discussing it with another person.   Curiously, the person is Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (honestly and simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss him. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sometimes I wake up in the  morning, and I think 'I have to make  Frank's breakfast,' and I... I get  up and there's a... a very good reason  for getting out of bed until... until,  of course, I remember. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss talking to him. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy's a child, you know, and  Mitch... (she shrugs a little  sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mitch has his own life. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad he stayed here today. I  feel safer with him here. (she sighs deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to rest now, Mrs.   Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No... don't go yet. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel as if I... I don't understand  you. And I want so much to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Mrs. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my son is... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son seems to be fond of you. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not quite sure how I feel about  it. I really don't know if I... like  you or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so important, Mrs. Brenner?   You liking me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so. My son is important  to me. I want to like any girl he  chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a faint smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I don't suppose it'll matter  much to anyone but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it might also matter to Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch has always done exactly what  he wanted to do. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not complaining. That's the mark  of a man.  But... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I... I wouldn't want to  be... be left alone. I don't think I  could bear being left alone.  I...  forgive me. This business with the  birds has me upset.  I... I don't  know what I'd do if Mitch weren't  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to the bed;  adjusting the pillow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try to sleep now, Mrs.   Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I were stronger. (she pauses and looks  toward the window.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think she's all right? Do you  think she's safe at the school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to go for her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't ask you to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you? I'd feel so much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just clear up here, and then  dress. She picks up the tray and starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie? At the door, Melanie turns.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: her face soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie's car turns and goes up School Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer shot of the car coming to a stop outside school.   Inside the school, we HEAR the children SINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I married my wife in the month of  June. Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo, mo  mo!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: smiling as she gets out of the car and heads for the scho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I carried her off in a silver spoon.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, hey bombosity,  knickety-knackety, retro-retroquo-  quality, willoby-wallaby, quo-mo,  mo, mo!  Uality, willoby-wallaby,  quo-mo, mo, mo! The CAMERA FOLLOWS Melanie into the school and down the  corridor. The children's VOICES are LOUDER now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She combed her hair but once a year.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, Mo, mo, mo!   With every rake, she shed a tear.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, hey bombosity,  knickety-knackety, retro-quo-quality,  willoby-wallaby, Mo, mo, mo! Melanie is at the door to Annie's room now. She opens the door and looks in. FULL SHOT - ANNIE - MELANIE'S P.O.V. leading the children in song. She catches sight of Melani at the door. Melanie wiggles her fingers. Annie points to her wristwatch indicating that she'll be finished in a fe minutes and motions for her to wait in the play-yard outs Melanie turns and starts down the corridor again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie emerges and strolls up street toward Annie's hous Inside the children are still singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She swept the floor but once a year.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo, mo, mo!   She swore her broom was much too  dear. Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, hey  bombosity, knickety-knackety, retro- quo-quality, willoby-wallaby, mo,  mo, mo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie turns back and seats herself on seat in front of  play yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She churned the butter in Dad's old  boot. Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo,  mo, mo!  And for a dasher she used  her foot.  Ristle-tee, rostle-tee,  hey bombosity, knickety-knackety,  retro-quo-quality, willoby-wallaby,  mo, mo, mo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A side profile of Melanie as she sits. Size of shot has s on bottom of screen. We are shooting three-quarter toward the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butter came out a grizzle-y-  ygrey.  Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, grey.   Mo, mo, mo!  The cheese took legs  and ran away!  Ristle-tee, rostle- tee, hey bombosity, knickety-knackety,  retro-quo-quality, willoby-wallaby,  mo, mo, mo!

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: Three-quarter angle on play yard behind Melanie. A CROW  alights on the Jungle Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought my wife a horse one day.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo, mo, mo!   She let the critter get away.  Ristle- tee, rostle-tee, hey bombosity,  knickety-knackety, retro-quo-quality,  willoby-wallaby, mo, mo, mo!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: a nearer cut of Melanie same angle as previous. Waist sho

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: again four more crows arrive.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Nearer shot of Melanie smoking. Same angle. Just above wa bust shot.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: Again five more crows arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: head and shoulders of Melanie as she sits smoking. There no sound except for the faint voices of the children sing inside the schoolhouse. Melanie is puffing away at her  cigarette and occasionally glances in the direction of th school. We hold on this shot of Melanie for a very long t so that we are able to express her ignorance of what is g on behind her with the crows. After a wait of about what  seems to be a half a minute or more, Melanie's attention drawn to something above her.

dialogues.speaker: SKY
dialogues.text: A crows is coming down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as her eyes follow the flight of the crow.

dialogues.speaker: SKY
dialogues.text: Crow moving down and LEFT to RIGHT, the sky and Annie's r in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her head has twisted around to follow the flight of the c She is almost looking into the play yard.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: A crow slowly descends to the play yard and as the CAMERA FOLLOWS it down, we see for the first time that the numbe of crows has increased to an alarming number - almost 200 even perhaps 250. This last crow settles down with the ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throughout preceding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked my wife to wash the floor.   Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo, mo, mo!   She gave me my hat and showed me the  door! Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, hey  bombosity, knickety-knackety, Retro-quo-quality, (the song slows -- it  is near the end)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoby-wallaby, mmmmmmmo, mmmmmmmoo, Mo! CLOSE SHOT - MELANIE The CAMERA WHIPS UP as she leaps to feet in alarm. Her body has turned, but we are now facing the opposite side of the school yard.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: The play yard is full of crows.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Big head of horrified Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD
dialogues.text: A closer view of the menacing birds.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Big profile of Melanie. She turns with back to CAMERA and goes toward school looking at crows as she goes away. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her for a few paces and then STOPS so that her image becomes smaller as she goes up steps into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A side view of the crows as seen by Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: THE INTERIOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Melanie in headlong flight toward Annie's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, children. Now please put  your books in your desks, and bring  the songsheets to the front of the  room. No one's going out to play  until I have all the songsheets.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Annie is lining the children up near the door leading to play yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going outside until we  quiet down. Ralph? Did you hear me? The children mutter for a moment, and then are still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now. She begins opening the play yard door. Suddenly, the door from the corridor bursts open, and Melanie rushes wildly  INTO the room. She goes directly to Annie, shoves her out the way, and SLAMS shut the play yard door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE AND MELANIE
dialogues.text: against a background of children's VOICES, as they react this new excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get the children out of  here. These big windows... there's  no way to board them up. Annie gives a quick nod, understanding immediately.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Through the windows, we can see the waiting crows. One mo restlessly into flight, then settles on the equipment aga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet down, children! Quiet down! The children modulate into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Daniels wants to see how we  conduct ourselves during a fire drill.  I'd like you to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling in Unison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire drill? This is our play period,  Miss Hayworth! Gee whiz!  Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to show her how quiet  and obedient you can be. The children again fall silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to go out of the school  now. Those of you who live nearby  can go directly home. I want the  rest of you to go down the hill, all  the way to the hotel. Do you  understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the way down the hill? Gee, Miss  Hayworth, we never... Home? Why do  we...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shushing them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to go as quietly as you  can, not a sound, until I tell you  to run. And then I want you to run  as fast as you can. Does everyone  understand? (pause - silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. John, would you lead the  class, please? The children walk two-by-two to the corridor door. John o it, and they begin filing out. Melanie turns to look at t play yard.

dialogues.speaker: A SINGLE CROW
dialogues.text: fluttering at the window, almost in exploration. He hangs there for a moment, then wings back to the playground  equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: straight on of all the crows.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD, (8)
dialogues.text: but a different angle.

dialogues.speaker: PLAY YARD, (10)
dialogues.text: but a different angle from the others

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low angle of five or six crows filling the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is filled with crows. About fifty or more. All a sudden we HEAR the distant PATTERING of children's feet they start running. Immediately the crows rise and the CA PANS UP with them into the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FULL SHOT showing the children running toward the CAM Annie herding them at the rear. The crows - about two hun rising over the schoolhouse roof and descending toward an reaching the running children. Shot as a moving backgroun with six or seven children in front on a treadmill with t mechanical birds coming into top of screen as though  continuing on from the plate. The birds swing around and  among the foreground children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A side view of running children with Melanie in front urg them forward. Birds fly between them, two or three others wheel around, one live one sweeps by in foreground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three or four children running. Birds overhead - one or t children spread out as others come in from sides and take their places. Birds swerve in and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Profile of running child. Bird catches up and bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nearer side on view without Melanie. Birds wheeling in out - others overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird on top of girl's head (showing feet and wings).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three-quarter back of two children running - lots of bi overhead and others wheeling. Screen almost full of birds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-half child's face - a bird's head and beak on left,  dashing round to the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of feet running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing the crows among the running children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big head of girl - bird lands on her right shoulder - win over her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One SCREAMING child as bird swoops from top left down to  lower right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head and shoulders of boy who ducks behind pole -- bird g by as another attacks him from right-hand side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back view of boy's head running. He looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big head of bird coming at CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back view of little girl running. She looks over her shou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big head of bird coming into CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
