dialogues.text: Straight back CLOSE SHOT of Annie dragging slow children. birds in back, but several wheeling around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: showing the crows chasing the children down the street -  with the Bay in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bird dives to head of Michele and she falls OUT of pict

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Michele as she hits ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her glasses smash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flash Cathy - she sees and runs back. Birds swirling arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six birds descend on fallen Michele - legs running by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy RUSHES IN. She disperses birds and bends to pick up Michele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie stops, looks back and sees Cathy and Michele, hea of other children rushing by in foreground. Birds swirlin Melanie dashes out left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie reaches Cathy and Michele -- Michele is now on he feet. Birds swirling -- Melanie looks about -- sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Station wagon across the street. Birds swirling about and children running by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie drags Cathy and Michele to the station wagon. We the Bay in the distance and children running on the botto of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting inside the wagon across the front seat. The thre scramble in, Cathy first, then Michele and Melanie last - the door SLAMS on crows swooping around. Cathy and Michel are SCREAMING with fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the windshield we see crows attacking. Bay and ru children in distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The faces of the three - Birds are fluttering on the rear window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wheel in foreground. She starts to slam hand on horn ring

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crows attacking side window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand on horn ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy and Michele's faces huddled together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie's big head - she looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knob of wiper -- her hand comes in and pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipers starting. Crows retreat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three faces staring out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through windshield. The crows are starting to go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie looks out and sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: through windshield. Annie running back with stick. She be the last of the crows away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie flops in exhaustion over the wheel as Annie comes round to the side window and starts to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is lunchtime and there is a busy bustle to the place a DEKE CARTER officiates behind the bar and HELEN CARTER, h wife, rushes back and forth between diners at the tables. DRUNK sits at the bar, old, grizzled, the weary wisdom of booze in him. In one of the booths sits SEBASTIAN SHOLES his shirt sleeves, eating a hurried lunch quickly and  efficiently. A WOMAN and TWO CHILDREN are seated at anoth table, about to order. A party of noisy SALESMAN is laugh and clowning around throughout following at a table in th rear. The phone from behind the bar has been placed on th counter, and Melanie is speaking into it while Deke liste Over her head, the television set is blasting with its  perennial Western, the gun shots punctuating her conversa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, there were hundreds of them.   No, I'm not hysterical, I'm trying  to tell you this as calmly as I know  how. All right, Daddy. Yes Daddy. (she takes a deep  breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now.  Not... fifteen minutes  ago. The door to the Tides opens and MRS. BUNDY, sixtyish, wea walking shoes and a tweed suit, a very masculine-looking  woman with short clipped white hair, comes in, passes thr foreground, goes to bar, her attention slowly caught by w Melanie is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the school. No, I don't. Just a  minute. (to Deke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the name of the school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the Bodega Bay School. (to Mrs. Bundy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you, Mrs. Bundy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need some change, Mr. Carter. As Deke opens cash register...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bodega Bay School. (to Deke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you turn that down, please? Deke gives Mrs. Bundy her change, turns off television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how many children. Thirty or forty. Yes. Mrs. Bundy goes to cigarette machine, pauses to listen to Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the birds didn't attack until  the children were outside the school.  Crows, I think. I don't know, Daddy.  Is there a difference between crows  and blackbirds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning from machine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is very definitely a difference,  Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're different, Daddy. (to Mrs. Bundy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think these were crows. Yes,  hundreds of them. Yes, they attacked  the children, attacked them. (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, a little girl was sent to the  hospital in Santa Rosa. Well, all  right, but you act as if I'm... all  right, all right. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't come home now. I just  can't, Daddy. How is it there? I  mean... are there birds? In the sky?   But no trouble. Well, I hope... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know when. I simply can't  leave now. Tell Mother not to worry.   All right, Daddy, good-by. She hangs up. Mrs. Bundy is at her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both perching birds, of  course, but of quite different  species. The crow is brachyrhynchos.  The blackbird is cyanocephalus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Deke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Dan Fawcett's number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the book right here, Miss. As Melanie looks it up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Bundy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see what difference it makes,  Mrs. Bundy, crows or blackbirds. If  they attacked the school, that's  pretty serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a superior smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly think either species would  have the intelligence to launch a  massed attack. Their brain pans aren't  large enough for such...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dialing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came from the school, madam.   I don't know about their brain pans  but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds are not aggressive creatures,  Miss. They bring beauty to the world.  It is mankind, rather, who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to door leading  to kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Southern fried chicken, Sam.   Baked potato on all of them. LAUGHTER from salesman at table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, may I speak to Mitch Brenner,  please? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing to Deke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...insist on making it difficult for  life to survive on this planet. If  it weren't for birds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bundy, you don't seem to  understand. This young lady says  there was an attack on the school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch? I'm glad I caught you.   Something terrible has happened. Her background conversation continues through following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about the school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunch of crows attacked the school,  Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the world. (suddenly quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Thus saith the Lord God to the  mountains, and to the hills, to the  rivers and to the valleys; Behold,  I, even I, will bring a sword upon  you, and I will destroy your high  places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord's not destroying anything,  Jason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "In all your dwelling places, the  cities shall be laid waste, and the  high places shall be laid waste!" (he nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ezekiel, Chapter six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Woe unto them that rise up early in  the morning that they may follow  strong drink."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isaiah, Chapter 5. It's the end of  the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, all right, I'll wait for you.   Good-by. (she hangs up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly think a few birds are going  to bring about the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These weren't a few birds.

dialogues.speaker: THE WOMAN AND THE CHILDREN
dialogues.text: waiting for their lunch, listening to the conversation;  becoming very nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even know there were many  crows in Bodega Bay this time of  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crow is a permanent resident  throughout its range. In fact, during  our Christmas Count, we recorded...

dialogues.speaker: SHOLES
dialogues.text: eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly, from his  table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many gulls did you count, Mrs.   Bundy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which gulls, Mr. Sholes? There are  several varieties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ones that've been raising the  devil with my fishing boats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably herring gulls. They arrive  in November, you know, and don't  migrate North again until March or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaping upon this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had trouble with gulls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my boats did last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making a connection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This young lady got hit by a gull  only Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick up the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now it's gulls. A minute ago, it was  crows. (she picks up tray,  shrugs, goes to table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deke, I'm still waiting for those  Bloody Marys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming right up!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: as Helen brings food. She is beginning to get really  frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you ask them to lower their  voices, please? They're frightening  the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Timmy has a canary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice. Are you Timmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin is Timmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving table, coming  to bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A whole flock of gulls nearby capsized  one of my boats.  Practically tore  of the skipper's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scaring the kids. Keep it  low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're scaring me, too. Are you trying  to say all these... (he shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds impossible, Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only telling you what happened  to my boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gulls were after your fish, Mr.   Sholes. Really, let's be logical  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were the crows after at the  school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think they were after,  Miss...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniels. I think they were after the  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To... (she hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To kill them. There is a long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought not. Birds have been on  this planet since archaeopteryx,  Miss Daniels; a hundred and twenty  million years ago! A TRAVELING SALESMAN ENTERS, goes to bar, listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it seem odd that they'd wait  all that time to start a... a war  against humanity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one called it a war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch, light on the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Mr. Sholes seem to be implying  as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you finished here, Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have some apple pie, Helen. (to Mrs. Bundy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said anything about war? All I  said was that some gulls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One apple pie! You want more coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. ...came down on one of my boats.   They could have been after the fish,  just as you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your captain should have shot at  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gulls are scavengers, anyway. Most  birds are. If you ask me, we should  wipe them all out. World would be  better off without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, birds. All they do is make a  mess of everything. Who needs them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if they're starting a war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are incapable of organized  warfare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen a jay protecting  a nest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have seen jays doing everything it  is conceivable for jays to do.   Ornithology happens to be my  avocation, Miss Daniels. You're  talking about preservation of the  species, a hen protecting her young.   There's a vast difference between...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they're all protecting the  species. Maybe they're tired of being  shot at and roasted in ovens and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you discussing gamebirds now?   All birds are not gamebirds, you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about birds  except that they're attacking this  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then fight back. Get yourselves guns  and wipe them off the face of the  earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would hardly be possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not, Mrs. Bundy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there are 8,650 species of  birds in the world today, Mr. Carter.  It's estimated that five billion,  seven hundred and fifty million birds  live in the United States alone. The  five continents of the world...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill them all. Get rid of them.   Messy animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...probably contain more than a  hundred billion birds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the world!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we seem to have more than our  share of them right now, Mrs. Bundy.   Maybe this young lady's right.  Maybe  they've all gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your pie, Sebastian. You want  it at the table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Here's fine. (he begins eating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the Bloody Marys, Deke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we running a business here -- or  a bird sanctuary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beginning to change  his mind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, those gulls must have been  after the fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes a lot more sense than... well,  an attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it does. If we believe  that birds are attacking, why... why  next we'll believe that grasshoppers  and cockroaches are capable of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cockroaches!  Urghh!

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: getting more and more anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, children. Finish your lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are the birds gonna eat us, Mommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we're all getting a little  carried away by this. Admittedly, a  few birds acted strangely. That's no  reason to believe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a few birds! I keep telling  you that! These are gulls and swifts  and crows and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what? Vultures? Hawks? Eagles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe! Is it impossible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I have never known birds of  different species to flock together.   The very concept is unimaginable. (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why if that happened, we wouldn't  have a chance. How could we possible  hope to fight them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't. You're right, Mrs.   Bundy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling from table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, may I have a check, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything all right, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I... I'm anxious to get on the  road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming from kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Something wrong  out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fighting a war, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A war? Against who? Did the  Russians...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you all think this is so  amusing. You've frightened my children  half out of their wits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not scared, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep quiet. If that young lady saw  an attack on the school, why won't  you believe her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What attack? Who attacked the school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds did. Crows! And you're all  sitting around here debating! What  do you want them to do next? Crash  through that window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened by her  mother)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet! Why don't you all get home?   Lock your doors and windows! (her hysteria rising)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on your coats, children! (to Deke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the fastest road to San  Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freeway, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going out that way, lady. You  can follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's go. Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't finished my drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on edge of panic,  shouting at her  children)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on your coats! Do you want to  get trapped here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find my scarf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look in your sleeve! The door opens. Mitch and Al Malone come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie? At the far table, the salesman begin singing, rowdily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got here as fast as I could.   Where's Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Annie's house. She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Al, why aren't you over there where  the attack was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I just got back from Dan  Fawcett's place, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was killed last night. By birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold it, Mitch. You don't know  that for a fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are the facts, Mr. Malone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa Rosa police think it was a  felony murder. They think a burglar  broke in and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the Santa Rosa police at your  school today? (impatiently, to  salesman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, lady. (through window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't a bird anywhere in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Look at the birds of the air: they  do not sow or read, yet your heavenly  father feeds them."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never feed another bird as long  as I live!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like this happened in Santa  Cruz last year. The town was covered  with seagulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you please finish your drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, sir, I recall it. A  large flock of seagulls got lost in  a fog and headed in for the town,  where all the lights were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made some mess, too, smashing  into houses and everything. (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They always make a mess. We're better  off without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is that no one seemed to  get upset about it. They were gone  the next morning, just as if nothing  at all had happened. Poor things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving! Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right! (he downs his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you figure this out, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the end of the world. The Tides is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd better get back to the  cannery. What do I owe you, Deke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see. Scallops and coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it just a minute, Sebastian. Sholes turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: his face very serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sebastian, I'm not an alarmist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one ever said you were, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're in trouble. I don't  know how or why this started, but I  know it's here and I know we'd be  crazy to ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore what? The bird war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the bird war, the bird attack,  the bird plague, you can call it  what you want to, they're out there  massing someplace and they'll be  back, you can count on that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bundy, why don't you go home  and polish your binoculars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't do something now, if we  don't get Bodega Bay on the move...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mitch, even if this is true,  even if all the birds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe it's true, Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't, Mitch. Because I can't  see any reason for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happening. Isn't that a good  enough reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Bodega Bay as well as any  man. If I thought... (he shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then help me, Sebastian. You're an  important man in this town. If you'll  help, the rest will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help how? What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't even know what you want  to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to him, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking position beside  Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen to him, Sebastian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only know we've got to drive them  away from town -- before they drive  us away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bundy, you said something about  Santa Cruz. About seagulls getting  lost in the fog, and heading in for  the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have any fog this time of  year, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make our own fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you plan to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an ordinance against burning  anything in this town, unless it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll use smoke pots. Like the Army  uses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What good'll that do? Smoke's as bad  as birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds are not bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we go on living here if we  blanket the town with smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we go on living here otherwise? Pause. They are silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth a try, Sebastian. There is more silence as they all consider. And then sudd

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! They turn toward the window.

dialogues.speaker: TIDES CAR PARK
dialogues.text: Viewed from the side window inside the Tides we see three four gulls diving down toward the highway over the roof o the Tides Office. Two more swoop into the foreground of t window and out to the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gulls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're only the usual... What are  you...

dialogues.speaker: TIDES TOWN
dialogues.text: The first gull reaches the gas station but misses the  attendant who is in the act of filling the car. The owner seen disappearing into the men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quick flash of the group of faces at the window of the  Tides Restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: TIDES TOWN
dialogues.text: A nearer view of the gas station. A second gull hits the on the back -- he falls -- hits his head on the pump and  then collapses over the gasoline hose pipe, pulling it ou and causing it to spill. The third and fourth gulls sweep by.  The gas begins to flow away.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: inside the Tides. Mitch dashes toward the door -- Melanie after him. Through the glass windows into the street we s people dashing off to the right, in the direction of the station. At the door, Mitch turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Melanie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay back in here. Deke Carter comes running from behind the bar to join Mit They both EXIT. Melanie dashes back to her original place the window. The CAMERA RETREATING with her, we come to th window and over Melanie's shoulder we see the men arrive rescue the attacked gas station attendant. Three or four gulls are still attacking and they flutter  away as the men appear to beat them off. Suddenly Melanie the foreground turns in full profile to her right and loo down.

dialogues.speaker: TIDES CAR PARK
dialogues.text: on the sloping pavement before her a stream of gasoline i flowing to the right into the car park.

dialogues.speaker: GASOLINE
dialogues.text: flowing down to the car park.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: through the window. She suddenly looks toward the gas sta

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA PANS
dialogues.text: along the flowing gas back to the station.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She turns back to the car park.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MELANIE'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: We see the flow of gasoline trickling toward the car park below her. At this particular moment, a car has pulled up has come to a stop and a man emerges. He is in the act of lighting his dead cigar, but his attention is drawn to th happenings around the gas station. With this half-drawn  attention, he strikes the match and holds it to the cigar

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: She quickly slides the window open and yells down to the  man.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MELANIE'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: The man looks about him, holding the match I his fingers. he catches sight of Melanie, the match burns his finger a he drops it.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Her horror-stricken face.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARKING AREA
dialogues.text: Three fast explosions in a row as the man's car, Mitch's  car, and the one next to it go up in flames.

dialogues.speaker: THE GAS STATION
dialogues.text: The line of flame running swiftly from the burning cars,  following the gasoline on the ground, directly to the pum which blows up as the men are jumping away with the injur attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very high shot shows the beginning of the people of the town rushing around the car park and the streets across t highway, endeavoring to put out the two fires. We see  automobiles coming to a stop on Highway One, and the oil  smoke beginning to rise from the burning gas station and parked cars. Some men have managed to start a fire hose a have trained it on the burning cars. Suddenly but slowly foreground in the sky just below the CAMERA begins to fil with wheeling gulls. The whole picture below becomes  obliterated by the foreground birds who now begin to swoo down on the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A raking shot outside the Tides Restaurant showing the ph booth and motel off in the background. People are rushing out from the restaurant and look up in the sky. Gulls beg to descend into the scene, driving the people back into t restaurant. Melanie is seen in the distance calling for M

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch...! Mitch! We see her look up to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: The sky is full of seagulls.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Looking about her frantically. She turns her face up agai to see the descending gulls. She is driven to take refuge the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE PHONE BOOTH
dialogues.text: slams the door shut. Gulls are now beating at the glass a around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Melanie's viewpoint inside the booth we see the peop who have been rushing to put out the fire now faced with  clouds of birds coming on them.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking out in terrified alarm but still searching with h eyes for Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: in the phone booth. She turns and looks swiftly in the  direction of the car park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some men have secured a hose and are obviously getting wa from the bay. They are turning the stream onto the burnin cars. At this time, the birds are filling the area around them. They suddenly turn the hose up into the birds.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Her eyes turn up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: FROM HER VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: We see the stream of water swing to and from among the bi Melanie turns back from this at the sound of a roaring ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a car zig zag down from the town in a drunken mann coming toward her in the phone booth.  We can see birds f in and out of the windows of the car.  We can see the arm and hand of the driver trying to beat them away. In the  background of this scene we see the fire truck arrive.

dialogues.speaker: THE HORRIFIED FACE OF MELANIE
dialogues.text: as the car comes toward her in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the last minute, the car swerves away from the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A side view of the car after practically scraping the sid of the booth. We see that it's full of birds attacking th driver. As it goes by, it near tilts over to inadvertentl give us a view of its interior.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: watching the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car goes on and smashes into the other burning cars. explodes.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: Suddenly she hears the firing of a gun. She turns.

dialogues.speaker: TIDES TOWN
dialogues.text: She sees a man with a gun shooting up at birds but to no  avail. One or two descend upon him. He throws the gun dow and rushes back into the Tides Office. Melanie, with a sl turn, now sees:

dialogues.speaker: THE TIDES TOWN
dialogues.text: The fire volunteers with birds descending around them dro their hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: shows the hose snaking wildly and jumping. At one moment water turns and comes in a powerful stream hitting the wi of the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: recoils from this water attack. Through the streaming win she sees the fire volunteers rushing away for cover. To t left we see a horse with its head covered with gulls; its palomino-colored body covered with crows. It is bucking a leaping and kicking its van to pieces. At this moment the scene is obliterated by the appearance a man groping his way closely past the phone booth window His face is poring with blood: his head and shoulders are covered with attacking birds. He disappears from sight.   Melanie, now almost in a faint, opens her eyes to see Tid Town. Through the booth window she sees Mitch and Deke Ca the owner of the Tides, coming down toward the CAMERA and waving the birds away from them with flailing arms.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: opens the booth doors and starts out with a cry of  recognition, but she has barely stepped out when more gul crash around the booth causing her to go back.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE IN PROFILE
dialogues.text: looking out again toward Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through window she sees Deke Carter run off in one direct while Mitch suddenly sees a child at the window of the bu building adjacent to the flaming and smoking gas station. Mitch dashes across and goes up the short staircase into smoking building.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking across in horror.

dialogues.speaker: THE BURNING BUILDING
dialogues.text: For a moment there is no sign of anyone about, then sudde Mitch appears with the small child at the window. He call down. One man dashes from the direction of the Tides Offi another from the Tides Restaurant. They both wait below t window as Mitch drops the child.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: watching this breathlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment the child has dropped, Mitch suddenly looks up He slams the window as two or three birds crash into the  windows. They disappear into the building.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: holding her breath.

dialogues.speaker: THE BURNING BUILDING
dialogues.text: No sign of Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: getting more desperate.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: No sign of Mitch. Suddenly a chair flies through the wind and Mitch climbs OUT and drops to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: opening the door of the booth, yells out to him.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: sees her and starts running toward the booth.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: beating his way through the birds. He reaches the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: close to the Tides Restaurant entrance. We see Mitch drag Melanie from the phone booth and run with her toward the  CAMERA through the birds into the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be at least twenty people all looking toward t windows. It is as though they are hiding from a storm. Th CAMERA is high enough to see Melanie and Mitch COME IN, v hurriedly close the door. We see the gulls wheeling outsi There is a kind of stunned silence among the people. We c hear the sound of the screaming gulls outside. Suddenly a woman's voice SCREAMS out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they doing it?! Why are they  doing it...?! Some of the heads of the group turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the woman who had the two children screaming at Mrs Bundy who is seated in a booth table staring numb and  helpless. Mrs. Bundy turns and looks at her and mutters s words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ([Mrs. Bundy offers a  weak explanation of  why the birds could  have gone berserk  like this. This  information should  be obtained from Dr.  Stager.])

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: looking across at this slight scene. They turn back and o their shoulders the gulls seem to be in much less quantit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're going. Melanie follows his look. At this moment there is a loud  CRASH OF GLASS. They turn their heads suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: FROM MITCH'S AND MELANIE'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: And past the heads of the other people who have also turn we see one of the back windows of the Tides Restaurant ha gone and gulls are coming in. Two or three of the men who are on the edge of the crowd turn and go back toward the  window, beating them out. They succeed in doing this.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: They turn from the gulls in the restaurant to look to the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's safe to get out now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let's take any chances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get Cathy. They open the door and make their way out into the street running and looking about them desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are one or two gulls flying around. Others are perc on roofs as we see Mitch and Melanie dashing along the  sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are still one or two gulls or crows in evidence as  they move along past the last street and come into the mo countrified part of the town.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCHOOL YARD
dialogues.text: We see them turn and dash up the road toward the school w we see in the distance. There are some birds perched on t school roof.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: going up the school road. He stops for a moment and looks up, Melanie following his look.

dialogues.speaker: FULL
dialogues.text: of wheeling gulls.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: They move on and go past Melanie's waiting car outside th school. Suddenly Melanie brings him to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: There are a few blackbirds on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... the crows again.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: Mitch starts off. Melanie restrains him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, Mitch. The crows may be  back in the play yard.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO
dialogues.text: They advance cautiously. When they are level with the pla yard, we see what they see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA DOLLIES along the play yard. It is again full crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk stealthily past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANNING ALONG the waiting crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting over the shoulders of Melanie and Mitch, they  approach Annie's house. Melanie glances apprehensively ov her shoulder toward the crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie and Mitch arrive. They come to a sudden stop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: A woman is crumpled lifelessly on the front steps before door.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He reaches the body. He rolls it over.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: dead.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: The shock registering on his face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: realizing that Annie is dead, and wondering for a moment  what Mitch's reaction will be. MED. SHOT - MITCH - MELANIE'S P.O.V. He kneels silently by the body. Gently, he touches Annie' face, and then gently and illogically takes off his jacke and covers her, as if he is tucking a blanket around her keep her warm. He turns away then.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: with its ROOM TO LET sign. Cathy is standing near the sig with her eyes peering at something outside.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: turning to follow Cathy's gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MIXED BIRDS
dialogues.text: Malevolent, sitting on the fence, the killers.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: As in fury, Mitch picks up stones and begins hurling them the birds. Melanie dashes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as the birds flutter  into the air)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch! Don't! She runs to him, grabs his arm, struggles with him as he  maniacally continues hurling stones at the birds, who are now hovering flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Get Cathy!  Let's get out of  here! Her words reach him. Breathing heavily, he goes INTO the  house and COMES OUT carrying Cathy, who is dazed and in a state of shock. The CAMERA PANS him over to Melanie who h Cathy to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Melanie looks anxiously toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, you can't leave her out there. He GOES OUT OF PICTURE. Melanie watches him. Over her sho is the white face of Cathy. We HEAR a DRAGGING SOUND and  then a door is CLOSED. MED. SHOT - MELANIE'S P.O.V. We see Mitch EMERGING from the house. The body is no long in the pathway. He comes toward the CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He joins Melanie and Cathy. The CAMERA MOVES AHEAD of the three of them as they silently make their way past the cr once more, Melanie holding Cathy close to her. They look cautiously to the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA DOLLYING PAST the crows again.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: They move forward stealthily, CAMERA AHEAD of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another DOLLY SHOT past the crows.

dialogues.speaker: THE THREE
dialogues.text: The CAMERA is now behind them. They move away from us and toward the waiting car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drive, Mitch. She goes round the far side and gets into the car. Mitch  slips in behind the driver's seat. The car turns into the CAMERA and goes down the school road.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: Mitch, Cathy and Melanie facing the CAMERA, tensely. Mela looks over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're coming. Cathy does not turn: she is staring ahead of her, her eye wide, her lip trembling. They drive in silence, and then  suddenly, Cathy begins speaking, almost as if to herself, the CAMERA COMES IN TIGHT on her face in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On our way back from taking Michele  home... we... we heard the explosion  and went outside to... see what...  what it was. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All at once the... the birds were  everywhere. All at once.  She... she  pushed me inside and... they covered  her. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pushed me inside.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY AND MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she takes the child in her arms to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - A LONE GULL flying low over the water, the C TRACKING it. The bay is silent. The gull spreads its wing to brake, and then sits on the water. The CAMERA continue low over the water, going through thousands of gulls sitt there patiently, as if it is threading itself through a c not a sound, over the gulls, and then lifting to show the Brenner house in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER HOUSE
dialogues.text: Behind the panes of glass, we can see the boards Mitch na across the windows. He is on the roof now, testing the tw attic dormer windows. He turns to look out over the bay.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAY
dialogues.text: covered with sitting gulls. In the distance, the town is  still smoldering. But the sky is clear of birds.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: picking up his hammer, sliding over the shingles to where the ladder leans against the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: as Mitch comes down the ladder and Melanie turns the corn carrying a load of driftwood and old lumber.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as she drops the wood outside the door and he joins her. is looking out over the bay when he comes to her. This is not the Melanie we saw at the beginning of the picture. H hair is disarrayed, and her face and clothing are streake with soot. But beyond a surface physical appearance, ther is a weary wisdom in her eyes, and a strength to her as s stands looking toward the distant smoldering town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town looks clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bay doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have they been gathering  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The past fifteen minutes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to be a pattern, doesn't  it? They strike and disappear, and  then they start massing again. Melanie nods. They are both silent, watching the bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep thinking of Annie. (she squeezes her  eyes shut)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It... it doesn't look very different,  does it? A little smoke over the  town, but otherwise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the birds sitting out there.   It does look very much the same,  Mitch. This could be last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may not be last week again for a  long long time. They are both silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. They're still coming. Mitch nods. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to try your father again? (Melanie shakes her  head.  Puzzled, Mitch  looks at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried a little while ago. The  phone's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we still got power?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (leaning against him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired, Mitch. I'm so very very  tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch! I'm getting something on the  radio!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia is hovering near the radio. Cathy is sitting on a  footstool. The windows are boarded, and the lights in the room are on. A tremendous amount of static is coming from the radio as Mitch and Melanie join them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get any of the local stations.   I think this is San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...would include formulation of a  central financing committee to handle  credit and to allocate responsibility  for the various facets of the project.  A vote on the motion is expected  early tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuing with the local news, police  are still investigating the series  of valuable jade burglaries in the  Chinatown area. The round-up of known  criminals has not as yet produced a  suspect, but Commissioner Nelson  said today he was certain the  burglaries were quote linked and the  work of the team of professionals  unquote. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Bodega Bay early this morning, a  large flock of crows attacked a group  of children who were leaving the  school during a fire drill. One little  girl was seriously injured and taken  to the hospital in Santa Rosa, but  the majority of children reached  safety in the town. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the national scene today, the  opening of the new session of Congress  was marked by a State of the Union  address that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...drew a standing ovation for the  President. The Chief Executive, in  discussing our relation to Europe  and the rest of the world community  said: "These various elements of our  foreign policy lead as I have said  to a single goal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to need more wood for  the fire. We can't let it go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing as drone  in background)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goal of a peaceful world of free  and independent states.  This is our  guide for the present and our vision  for the future -- a free community  of nations, independent but  interdependent, uniting north and  south, east and west, in one great  family of man, outgrowing and  transcending the hates and fears  that rend our age.  We will not reach  that goal today or tomorrow.  We may  not reach it in our lifetime.  But  the quest is the great adventure of  our century.  We sometimes chafe at  the burdens of our obligations, the  complexity of our decisions, the  agony of our choices, but there is  no comfort or security for us in  evasion, no solution in abdication,  no relief in irresponsibility. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In assuming the tasks of the  Presidency, I said that few  generations, in all history, had  been granted the role of being the  great defender of freedom in its  hour of maximum danger.  This is our  good fortune, and I welcome it now  as I did when I first took office. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For it is the fate of this generation --  Of you in the Congress and of me as  President -- to live with a struggle  we did not start, in a world we did - not make. But the pressures of life  are not always distributed by choice.  And while no nation has ever faced  such a challenge, no nation has ever  been ready to seize the burden and  the glory of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you you get the windows in the  attic, Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got them all, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you think they'll come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there are... larger birds, Mitch...  they'll get into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a chance we have to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we ought to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now.  Not while they're massing  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know when.  We'll see what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet.  I think we'll be  safe here. (Pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's bring that wood in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens when we run out of wood? Music begins to play.  The music is sweet, with violins a long piano arpeggios, almost too much to bear against the tension being played in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. We'll break up the  furni...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know, you don't know!   When will you know? When we're all  dead? Like Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieking it, her  face white)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at Mitch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your father were here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! I'm trying my best! (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... trying... my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling, nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: the strain showing on his face. He nods briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get the wood. Why don't you  make us all some coffee, Mother?

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: as Melanie and Mitch come out and head for the pile of wo There is a NOISE in the sky. Startled, glancing upward, t begin to run back toward the house and then stop and slow scan the sky.

dialogues.speaker: ENORMOUS FLOCK OF BIRDS
dialogues.text: flying in tight formation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they heading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santa Rosa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: watching the birds. A look of utter sadness crosses her f It is clear that she is thinking the birds will reach San Rosa, and eventually San Francisco as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's get this wood in. Melanie nods. But the look of sadness stays on her face, her eyes remain on the sky.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Lydia is pouring coffee into cups. In the dining room, we can HEAR the CHATTER of the lovebirds. As Lydia pours the sound distracts her. Cathy is sorting candles at the couc There is evidence of preparation everywhere: flashlights, kerosene lamps, a butane burner. Mitch is at the fireplac putting more wood on the fire. Melanie comes into the roo and dumps another load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you close the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And locked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, can I bring the lovebirds in  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, they're in a cage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're birds!

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: studying his mother, realizing how close she is to breaki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them stay in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: her hand trembling as she pours the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: as they all sit and accept their coffee. The room is sile except for the CRACKLE of the fire. Mitch rises to put mo wood on the fire. In the dining room, the lovebirds still are CHATTERING wildly. Their chirping is the only sound i the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch? Why are they doing this?  The  birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting wood on fire)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they trying to kill people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could say. But if I could  answer that, I could also tell you  why people are trying to kill people. The room is silent again except for the TWEETING of the  lovebirds offscreen. And then, suddenly, the lovebirds fa silent.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: turning to look toward the other room, her face going whi her eyes widening.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: waiting.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: dead silent now. Each of them is sitting on the edges of  their chairs, waiting. There is the SUDDEN SOUND of  splintering glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh. Shhh. Silence. Into the silence, another pane of glass, SHATTER the THUD of a bird against the boards. Silence.  More pan of glass SHATTERING. The SOUND of birds striking the boar and the outside of the house begins building, almost like muffled drumbeats. THUD, THUD, with an irregularity of rh Interspersed, like the counterpoint in an alien orchestra is the FLUTTER of wings. And then, like another section  entering, we begin to hear the SCRATCHING and CLAWING at roof.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: looking up toward the roof, the SOUND getting louder. She squeezes her eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY AND MELANIE
dialogues.text: as the child cuddles up into her arms. Over the other sou there comes a NEW SOUND, the unmistakable rat-tat-tat-tat of a woodpecker. It stops. It begins again. Rat-tat-tat t tat. Tat-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm sick, Melanie. I want.. I  want to throw... Her face pale, she rises suddenly and starts for the bath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with you. They leave the room. Mitch and Lydia sit in silence. We H Cathy retching offscreen, almost drowned out by the shuff of wings and the rasping of claws, the incessant thudding birds striking the house.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Mitch rises and puts more wood on the fire. The SOUND of birds is still everywhere around the house. He looks at h watch. He rises, walks into the kitchen to check the back door. It seems all right. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him into the dining room. He stops at the cage with the lovebirds.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOVEBIRDS
dialogues.text: watching him. Is there menace or innocence in their eyes? He cannot tell.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: looking at the lovebirds in puzzlement. There is suddenly NEW SOUND offscreen, the splintering of wood, the tearing sound of bigger beaks. Alarmed, he turns.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: coming into the entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: The wood is beginning to splinter as the bigger birds out assail the door.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: turning quickly, the CAMERA FOLLOWING him into the dining room. He pulls the cloth off the table, begins moving it  toward the door. In the entry, he lifts the table on end piles it against the door. He goes into the kitchen again CAMERA FOLLOWING. He upends the enamel-topped table, drag it to the back door. He is piling chairs against the tabl when Melanie COMES IN. She looks at what he is doing with alarm. Mitch looks in the direction of where his mother i and then back to Melanie, with an expression almost of  desperation. Both turn back to the barricaded door. The  CLAWING and the PECKING fills the void. The noise is a di now, insidious and increasingly more frightening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will they stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they'd have stopped by  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost two a.m.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you? She shakes her head. They both move into the dining room, the CAMERA FOLLOWING THEM. The lovebirds are sitting in t cage, close together, silent. Mitch picks up a chair, rea to carry it to the front door. He hesitates, puts down th chair, goes to the cage.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: looking at the birds, wondering.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIRDS
dialogues.text: looking back at him. Again, it is impossible to read thei expressions. Malice or benevolence?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: He raises his hand, brings it toward the bars of the cage

dialogues.speaker: THE BIRDS
dialogues.text: watching, unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH'S FINGER
dialogues.text: as he thrusts it through the bars. The birds sit unmoving One of them tweets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if Cathy fed them. He turns away from her, goes to the cupboard, opens the d takes out a small box of bird feed.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAGE
dialogues.text: as his hand approaches the door. The birds are watching h His hand hesitates. Then his thumb and forefinger lift th small catch on the cage door. His fingers open the door. Cautiously, in TIGHT CLOSEUP, his hand goes into the cage The birds sit and watch. One of them tweets. He removes t small feeding tray, puts the bird seed into it, replaces in the cage. The birds hesitate another moment. Then,  tweeting, they begin to eat.

dialogues.speaker: THE DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: as Mitch closes the door to the cage. Melanie is slumped  against the wall. He goes to her and takes her in his arm Wearily, she raises her head. The SOUND of the shuffling, pecking, clawing birds is everywhere around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have left when you wanted  to. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd have been safe in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be safe. I want to  be with you. There is something pathetically comic about her voice, li a small child's, confused but defiant. Holding her close, Mitch laughs, and she laughs with him. Exhausted, they st in each other's arms, laughing in that weary, silly, dead night sort of way. And suddenly... The lights go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in the darkness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here. Don't move. The screen is totally black for perhaps five seconds. In blackness, we HEAR the birds clawing and ripping, and the SOUND is enormously MAGNIFIED. A flashlight suddenly goes on.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as he comes to her with the flash. We see them only dimly he directs the beam upwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd better light some of those lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... wait. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold me. In the near darkness, we see them embrace and kiss. It is almost black in the room except for the strange effect of the flashlight as he holds it behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're easing off.

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: A kerosene lamp is burning. Melanie is awake, watching th fire. Lydia has fallen into a semi-recumbent position asl on the couch. Cathy is curled up in one of the easy chair Mitch is asleep by the fire. The fire is burning brightly and steadily. The house is almost still. There is no long the sound of the clawing and pecking, but there is anothe SOUND now: the sound of SOMETHING FALLING, or dropping in steady dribbling, difficult to place.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: listening to the curious sound, trying to fathom its mean

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she turns toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch?

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: asleep.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: seeing this, making her decision. The SOUND is still comi from somewhere in the house. She decides to let Mitch sle picks up a very long flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: as she goes through the house, checking. She stops in the entry hall, plays the flashlight over the furniture piled against the door. Everything seems all right. She goes in the kitchen, again, checks the door, and then plays the b on the boarded windows. Satisfied, she goes down the corr outside the bedroom. She opens the first bedroom door, en goes to the windows, plays the beam on them.  Everything' all right. She comes into the corridor again, opens the s bedroom door, again checks windows, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: climbing the steps to the attic. She stops outside the fi door upstairs, opens it, goes into the room, plays the li on the windows. Nothing. She comes out into the corridor, goes to the second bedroom, opens the door, enters, walks the windows. They are boarded securely. She is starting b toward the door when she stops.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: looking.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLOOR
dialogues.text: a pile of chipped and broken plaster.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning the flashlight up toward the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: THE CEILING
dialogues.text: A huge hole in it, showing moonlit sky outside.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: turning her eyes from the ceiling, determination on her f and suddenly, her eyes open wide.

dialogues.speaker: AN OWL
dialogues.text: sitting in the darkness, staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: reacting.

dialogues.speaker: THE OWL
dialogues.text: wings spread in the beam of light.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: backing to the door. The owl hits her, sends her staggeri back, causing the door to slam shut. She looks up at the

dialogues.speaker: THE CEILING
dialogues.text: a swarm of mixed birds coming through the hole and down t her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: in the room swinging the lighted flashlight as the birds  attack her.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: in the room, as the owl hits her full in the face.

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: swinging the flashlight as the birds attack her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie!

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE AND THE BIRDS
dialogues.text: grotesque and silent as she struggles with them. The room a crossing cacophony of mixed light beams and fluttering  wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie, open the door! He hurls himself against it. Inside the room, where Melan struggles, we HEAR his hammering on it. Melanie is overwh by the birds. She falls to the floor, the flashlight beside her. In the spreading rays of the light, we see the frantic flutterin of wings as the birds cover her. There is a stronger assa on the door by Mitch outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitch, get her out of there!

dialogues.speaker: THE ROOM
dialogues.text: Melanie, collapsed at the base of the door, is no longer view. Neither are the birds, whose fluttering shadows we on the door as Mitch again hits it from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie! The door begins to open.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as the door bursts inward and he stumbles into the room. begins swinging at the birds immediately, reaching down f Melanie, fighting off the attack at the same time. He beg dragging her out of the room. Her clothes have almost bee shredded from her body, and her face is torn and bleeding We catch only quick glimpses of her near-nudity, as Mitch pulls her into the corridor and then, holding the door sh behind him with one hand, delivers swinging furious blows the few birds that have escaped into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, get a rope!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, look at her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a rope! She rushes off. He struggles grotesquely with the birds. There is a wild fury in him, and a methodical dedication. will not allow them to defeat him. A large bird strikes h hand, knocking the club from it.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as the bird strikes at his face. He reaches out with his  hands, grasping the bird, letting go of the door knob.   Another bird flutters into the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: in anger and desperation as he throttles the bird with hi hands. He reaches behind him to grab the doorknob again, is immediately attacked by the other bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA AND MITCH
dialogues.text: as she runs up the steps and into the corridor, carrying heavy piece of rope. Mitch grabs the bird and hurls it an to the floor. Lydia is staring down at Melanie in terror compassion. He takes the rope from her, loops it over the doorknob, pulls it taut across the hallway, and ties it t the bannister, sealing the door. He turns immediately to  Melanie, picks her up and carries her to the steps, Lydia following. As they go downstairs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cathy! Get a blanket and some  bandages!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the foot of the  stars, on the verge  of tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: MELANIE
dialogues.text: cradled against Mitch's shoulder, her face bleeding profu

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he carries her into the living room, but her down on t couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just lie there and keep still. Cathy rushes to them with a roll of bandages and a blanke By the light of the lantern, Mitch drapes the blanket ove Melanie and then begins unrolling the bandage. But his ha are trembling, and he drops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me do that, Mitch. She picks up the bandage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you can. (her eyes meet his)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'd like to. He nods. Silently, she begins working on Melanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't mess me up with bandages,  Mrs. Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. But she begins cleaning the wounds, taping bandages over cuts. The house is still. She works silently and quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she works)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not very good at this, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Apologizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean. I want to... Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen!

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: raising her eyes. The room is silent. There is nothing to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone. God have mercy, they're  gone.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: as he goes to the front door, and cautiously moves away t table and chair. He opens the door a crack.

dialogues.speaker: THE YARD
dialogues.text: through the crack. Daylight is almost here. There are no  birds visible.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: from outside as Mitch opens it wider. The door is scarred and splintered. As he opens the door, one or two dead bir spill into the room. He steps out into the yard. Lydia is directly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: a shambles, all the windows broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone. The same pattern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can we go, Mitch? There's no  place to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to try for San Francisco.   There are buildings there. Steel and  concrete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd never make it. They're probably  all over the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to try it. (a long silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't stay here. (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Melanie needs help. (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, the house won't take another  attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If... when we get to San Francisco... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're already there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll worry about that when we get  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm frightened, terribly frightened.   I... I don't know what's out there,  Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we have to know, Mother?   We're all together, we all love each  other, we all need each other. What  else is there? Mother, I want us to  stay alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding; then after  a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started to say... inside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to. He holds out his hand to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'd better get started.

dialogues.speaker: THE BRENNER YARD
dialogues.text: It is covered with the eerie half-light that comes just b dawn, a light that persists throughout all of the followi until the penultimate shot in the picture. The silence is deafening. There is not a bird in sight. The door to Mela convertible are open as she and Mitch come out of the hou together and he helps her to the car. He puts her in the  back seat, tucks the blanket around her. In the backgroun is the pickup truck, too small to hold all of them. Lydia comes to the door and quickly crosses the yard, not looki down at the dead birds. Cathy appears in the doorway to t house.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY
dialogues.text: She is carrying the cage of lovebirds. She hesitates just outside the doorway. She looks at Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: looking back at her.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY, MITCH, AND LYDIA
dialogues.text: Across the expanse of the desolated yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I take them, Mitch? He does not answer. She continues looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't harmed anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slow nod)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
